title: strictly come dancing 2018 week two joe sugg tess daly claudia winkleman
story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsCouples receive mixed reviews as competition heats upClick to followThe IndependentIt was the first competitive night of the series and the Strictly Come Dancing judges were feeling particularly brutal. You can only imagine the producers’ faces as they watched Craig and co annihilate one dance after the other, failing to find anything to get excited about.&nbspIt picked up after the first few numbers though, and Danny, Faye, Joe and Ashley all got rave reviews. They loved Kate’s sultry tango with Aljaz too.&nbspThe relief got to Tess and she started laughing uncontrollably at one of Claudia’s only mildly amusing jokes, which was a bit awkward. Oh and Rob Beckett read out the Ts and Cs while Bruno managed another reference to Bodyguard. (When will he move onto Killing Eve like the rest of us? Maybe Halloween week?).Here’s what everyone is talking about as they await tomorrow night’s results…Joe Sugg is really having a moment. Sure, he’s been a YouTube sensation for some time, but now the mainstream are falling in love with him too. Everyone adores him, even though he’s dancing to Cotton Eye Joe, dressed a roof thatcher – superstardom beckons.His jive really hit the spot tonight, but Seann and Katya’s failed to impress. They weren’t in time to the music and panic set in. It didn’t help that they danced to Elton John’s I’m Still Standing, the music used for Jill Halfpenny’s iconic glitterball-clinching routine in series two, which is still being talked about more than a decade later. Surely Katya should have known better. Still, the judging gave Shirley and Seann a chance to make up, as she now likes his hair. Which is a relief for all of us.But Danny is hot on their heels. Faye and Giovanni’s Viennese Waltz will have alienated viewers who like a traditional approach – it was really an Argentine tango piece of storytelling trapped within a waltz. Of course it was beautifully executed though, and the judges loved it. Ashley’s silver tassled cha cha to Boogie Wonderland was an instant crowd-pleaser and allowed her to claim the top spot on the leaderboard, relegating Faye to number two. But don’t make the mistake of thinking this is a two-horse race – Danny is absolutely killing it. He’s feeling all those rehearsals in his feet and legs, but out on the dance floor he looks fabulous. One to watch.Vicky Gill and her team do an incredible job in the Strictly costume department, but every serues nightmares still happen. Janette Manrara is a salsa specialist and Dr Ranj is a brilliant student, so their routine should have been a highlight. But disaster struck when part of Janette’s dress got stuck on the heel of her shoe, restricting her movement for a good 20 seconds. Dr Ranj must have been secretly horrified but, props to him, you couldn’t see it on his face. He did a brilliant job, to much acclaim from the judges, but you can’t help feeling it could have been better. Shame.Janette Manrara's dress got stuck on the heel of her shoe as she danced with Dr Ranj Singh. (PA)Lauren has spoken very openly about two things so far this series. One: how she wants to inspire other girls with disabilities to feel that they can dance. Two: that she’s a competitive athlete by trade and wants to win. It was probably a heady mix of these two considerations that made her agree to sit on AJ’s shoulders during their Charleston and then fall face forward towards the floor with only one hand to catch herself. It really was a wow moment. If only the rest of the routine had been as exhilarating…Susannah and Anton finished at the bottom of the leaderboard, with Graeme and Oti, Seann and Katya and Katie and Gorka just above them. Tomorrow night we’ll face the first dance-off of the series (which seemed to come as a shock to Dr Ranj, like a child discovering Santa Claus isn’t real) and two couples will be fighting to make it through to Movie Week next time. Anton has his own very loyal army of fans, so don’t expect to see him waving goodbye tomorrow. It’s the couples in that dangerous mid-leaderboard position that should be worried. Vick and Graziano, I’m looking at you.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?Anyone can post in open comments. But NOA's pitch is that it's not a competition at all, and that audio can be about showing off some of the best traditional journalism in an entirely new setting.While audio is perhaps the oldest of all forms of media, the ways it is being delivered to people isn't at all. The advent of Amazon's Alexa, for instance, heralded an entirely new form of listening within the home, favouring on-demand cuts of information that can be requested by shouting while doing the washing up traditional radio still exists but it is increasingly being delivered over the internet when people ask, rather than as traditional broadcast.And the growth of ways to listen has come with an expansion of the listening public, too. With on-demand audio, people have come to see (or hear) that there are various times of the day that go largely unfilled, and it's apps like NOA – as well as other major audio companies like Audible – that are rushing into stop them being so silent.Amazon Alexa will now listen for strangers in your houseNOA works in a relatively simple way: its team take the best of their partners' written content, have a narrator record it, and push it out into the world. Its audience can then listen however and whenever they want, simply by opening up the app on their phone or asking Alexa to do it for them.The great thing about it is the time you have each day to consume visual content is limited, says Gareth Hickey, co-founder and CEO at NOA. You might take a quick look at a screen in the morning, and an hour or two in the evening. And that time can be filled up not just with news or other media like on demand television and Netflix, but also social media, emails and WhatsApp.Audio, however, doesn't have to compete: it can be done while driving, walking, exercising or doing something else entirely, and so can be a complement rather than distraction.About half of NOA's consumption comes between 7am and 9am. That gap in the day there just gets a lot of traffic – it's people that are usually commuting.There are of course many companies vying for that time too, many of them new. Everything from the shortest podcast to the longest of Audible's audiobook is intended to take on that market.But there is an awful lot of that time, too, and it is often spent doing a variety of different things. That means that companies like NOA seeing themselves as complementing podcasts rather than challenging them.That's useful become some companies like the New York Times have invested heavily in podcasts.They try much own that experience, and they're doing a great job with that. They're putting a huge amount of thought and time into getting that right.Instead, NOA focuses on the traditional articles that continue to do so well for those publishers. It is not about the kind of lengthier chats that often make up the meat of podcasts, but rather taking the quality content that news organisations are already producing it and recording it so people can listen to it another way.The style of content that we tend to lean more and more towards is the opinion, analysis, features, he says. The kind of articles that you might come across on a busy Monday afternoon and might not have the time to read.When people do come to those articles, they tend to spend a decent amount of time: about 85 per cent of people coming to an article will finish it, and they'll stay for an average of four-and-a-half minutes.NOA, of course, has some of the same struggles as every other news publisher. One of them is ensuring that people feel they can make their way through the vast amount of information that's out there in a way that's comprehensive and meaningful – without feeling completely overwhelming.One of the things we're moving towards has been an attempt to bring finish-ability to news topics, he says. It's all very well reading one piece about Brexit or business or whatever else, but with those huge issues it cane difficult to know where to start or where to end.One approach that NOA has been taking is to gather those topics up into playlists. One about electric cars, for instance, might include a more general overview on the industry, a e into the cobalt shortage that is threatening the batteries that power them, and a look at the latest scandal Tesla and Elon Musk have become embroiled in.It all helps to make people feel like it's possible to reach the end of the news, even if it's just to find that some more news has happened. When there is such an often overwhelming amount of stories – and stories about those stories – NOA like other more traditional publishers in seeking ways to cut through the noise.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?Anyone can post in open comments. title: japanese space agency asteroid jaxa latest pictures images
story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsClick to followThe IndependentThe Japanese space agency has released stunning new pictures taken by a rover standing on top an asteroid.The images, sent down from the surface of the asteroid Ryugu, show the rock in amazing and eerie detail. They were sent back over a distance of around 180 million miles.They come after the space agency successfully landed two rovers on the asteroid, dropping them from a spacecraft floating just above the surface.The rovers dropped down onto the asteroid by the Hayabusa-2 spacecraft are the first mobile exploration robots ever to land on an asteroid's surface. The images they are sending back are the first time that anything has ever autonomously moved and taken pictures themselves on asteroid, too.One of the pictures includes the shadow of the antenna and pin of the rover itself.​ The pin – which is the long line that can be seen sticking out of the rover – helps increase friction when they engage in the hops that they use to jump around the surface, among other purposes.Jaxa, the Japanese space agency, says that both of the rovers are in good condition and are transmitting images and data. The pictures they are sending back have confirmed that they are moving themselves around the asteroid's surface.The rovers will spend their time exploring the planet's surface by being joined by yet another visitor,&nbspcalled Mascot, built by scientists in Germany and France, that will further explore the surface.The new pictures are the second batch to be sent down by the&nbspHayabusa-2 spacecraft. The first were taken as the two rovers tumbled to the surface, and show their whirling motion as they fall.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?Anyone can post in open comments. story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsExclusive: Cabinet&nbspministers go cold on Ms May's approach as she prepares ‘Chequers 2’Click to followIndy PoliticsCabinet ministers trying to steer the prime minister away from her Brexit proposals will hold back from giving them full support and even try to avoid using the word “Chequers” in interviews,&nbspThe Independent&nbsphas learnt.Several members of the cabinet will use the approach to signal that patience with Theresa May’s strategy has waned, in a bid to ease her towards pursuing a free trade deal arrangement.Indications are emerging in Whitehall that Ms May is preparing a “Chequers 2” approach to be laid out after conference, but with changes to accommodate Brussels rather than Tory Brexiteers who want on overall looser arrangement with the EU.It comes ahead of the&nbspTory conference in Birmingham at which attempts to showcase&nbspa domestic policy agenda&nbspare likely to be overshadowed by Brexit squabbling.One cabinet minister told&nbspThe Independent&nbspit was obvious the Chequers deal as it stood was “not going to work” either for Brussels or for the parliamentary party.“We do need to find a way of refining the tune,” the minister&nbspsaid.Another indicated they would try to steer clear of actually saying the word “Chequers” when talking about policy to try and let it slip from the public discourse.Foreign secretary Jeremy Hunt enraged Downing Street when he suggested last week that the government could still be open to a Canada-style free trade deal with the EU.The cabinet will meet again on the first Tuesday after the conference, with many having felt that an opportunity to pressure the prime minister at its previous meeting was lost.Another senior minister said the PM’s top team needed to show her a way out of the impasse she finds herself in, while&nbspalso not destabilising the party by undermining her, describing it as “gentle encouragement”.Sir John Major condemns Boris Johnson for ‘routine attacks’ on PMClark insists ‘we need to have a Brexit deal’, contradicting MayGovernment to face legal challenge over Brexit inquiryFinal Say: Rod Stewart backs calls for second referendum on BrexitIt will come ahead of the October European Council summit, by which time Ms May was meant&nbspto have a&nbspdeal wrapped up.&nbspThere may now be a further summit&nbspin November.Rather than abandoning her plans, there is instead speculation in Whitehall that Ms May will amend the parts relating to her proposed customs set up to make them more acceptable to Michel Barnier and his EU negotiating team.The move may provoke criticism from Brexiteers that she is breaking her pledge not to join a customs union, as she continues to resist the shift to Canada-style trade deal.Ms May will deny making a U-turn on Chequers and officials have already dubbed the idea “Chequers 2”.It comes amid a vicious Tory row on the eve of conference after Boris Johnson publicly attacked Ms May’s Brexit plans.The former foreign secretary used a round of television interviews on Friday to lash out at her negotiating strategy, refusing to rule out a leadership challenge or voting against a Brexit deal.His comments, which followed a lengthy newspaper article attacking the Chequers plan, were then criticised by his political opponents within the party.The Absolutely.”The EU sees Brexit talks as Britain’s ‘managed capitulation’The comments are the strongest evidence yet that moderate Tories are flexing their muscles to prevent Theresa May carrying out her threat to allow the UK to crash out of the EU if necessary.Some senior cabinet ministers are also believed to be alarmed that the UK could end up facing a no-deal Brexit “by accident” and want the prime minister to adopt looser, Canada-style&nbsptrade proposals as a fallback.Speaking on ITV’s Peston programme, Ms Rudd warned hardline anti-Brexit Tory MPs that continuing to obstruct Ms May’s efforts to reach an agreement in Brussels could backfire on them.&nbsp“I don’t think no deal will happen,” she said, arguing a Norway-style EEA deal&nbsp– effectively keeping the UK in the EU single market – remained a possibility.And she said: “It would be ironic indeed if we got a people’s vote because the more Brexity people in my party were unable to support the prime minister in her than enough to defeat it, in alliance with opposition parties.May and Trump talk ‘big, ambitious’ post-Brexit trade at UNBrexit ‘poses severe threat’ to fight against drug harm and crime Jeremy Corbyn Chequers proposals – which have been rejected outright by EU leaders.Last month, Nick Boles, a former Tory minister, warned party hardliners that their “dream” of a no-deal Brexit would be blocked by at least 40 fellow Conservatives.And The Independent revealed in June that they could use a “humble address” – the tactic Labour used to force the government to release Brexit economic assessments – to prevent it.Meanwhile, Barry Gardiner, the shadow trade secretary, told the same programme that Jeremy Corbyn’s conference speech did amount to Labour “bending” its red lines on Brexit.In the address, the Labour leader said he would back a deal brought back by the prime minister if it kept the UK in a customs union and protected jobs, workers’ rights and environmental standards.Mr Corbyn did not mention the “six tests” previously set out by Sir Keir Starmer, the shadow Brexit secretary, which demanded the “exact same benefits” as the test for backing an agreement.Mr Gardiner said: “All of us don’t want the no deal that will take us off the edge of that cliff.“And if it means compromising, if it means you bending your red line to give us a customs union, we’re prepared to bend story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsElections expert Sir John Curtice&nbspsays chance&nbspof a second vote has 'grown' after Labour left open the possibility of backing it at its annual conferenceClick to followIndy PoliticsRemain would be ahead in a fresh referendum on Britain’s EU membership, according to a poll-of-polls tracker headed by the elections expert Professor Sir John Curtice.&nbspResearch&nbspby the National Centre for Social Research&nbspclaims that a majority (52 per cent) of British people currently want to stay inside the bloc while 48 per cent would opt to leave.&nbspUsing the average share of the vote in six of the most recent polls that have queried voting intention in a second referendum, the organisation launched its rolling tracker in order to “cut through the white noise that surrounds inidual polling results”.I’m not worried we’re stockpiling Brexit food – if anything, I’m gladMinister to oversee protection of food supplies amid no-deal fearsWhy Labour backing a vote on Brexit would strengthen the far rightUK car manufacturing falls again as industry demands Brexit safeguardIf May offered a final say on Brexit, she would win another electionAfter Labour left the door open to backing a new public vote during its annual conference, Sir John, who is a senior research fellow at NatCen, said the possibility of voters being asked again whether or not Britain should leave the EU had “grown”.&nbspBut he continued: “It remains far from certain that a second ballot would deliver a the pro-Remain majority that most of those who have been campaigning for another vote seem to anticipate.&nbsp“True, Remain enjoys a lead in the polls. But that lead is a narrow one, and there is little sign of it growing. Moreover, it rests quite heavily on the preferences of those who did not vote two years ago, and who by two to one say they would back Remain. Getting them to turn out in any second ballot might yet prove a considerable challenge.&nbspThe key dates on the UK’s journey to leaving the EU“That said, those in the Conservative Party who would like a ‘hard’ Brexit and who are minded to put pressure on Ms May in next week’s party conference to ‘chuck Chequers’, need to bear in mind that they may not be able to afford to take the risk that failure to back the government tips the country into a second ballot.&nbsp“For it seems that such an eventuality could see them lose the prize they secured two years ago.”&nbspThe Independent has already launched its own Final Say campaign for a fresh referendum on any final Brexit deal the prime minister returns from Brussels with and a petition backing the demand has nearly 840,000 signatures.The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.Sign our petition hereShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsExclusive: Damian&nbspGreen tells The Independent&nbspit is time for Conservatives to focus their fire on Labour&nbspClick to followIndy PoliticsTheresa May’s former deputy has urged the Conservatives to stop squabbling about Brexit and aim their fire on Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour Party or risk losing power at the next election.Damian Green told The Independent his party’s conference in Birmingham must be the first step in refocusing the party’s goals towards domestic policy that “help people in their daily lives”.The ex-cabinet member, who was one of the prime minister’s closest allies, spoke out as Ms May faced a wall of criticism from her party, with many MPs apparently spooked by what one ex-May aide described as Mr Corbyn’s “populist and clever” performance at Labour conference last week.Johnson unveils ‘better Brexit’ plan as he tells May to scrap ChequersThree cabinet ministers told The Independent they backed Mr Green’s call for a refocusing, but would not go on record for fear of undermining a prime minister weakened by continuous infighting and backbiting.A number of MPs said they did not think it would be possible to really talk about anything but Brexit this week, nor to refocus the party until Ms May had moved aside for a new leader.Mr Green’s intervention follows three days in which a number of prominent Conservatives have beseeched their party to take Mr Corbyn and his agenda seriously as an electoral threat.He told The Independent: “The Labour conference reminded us as a party that in the end elections are won or lost on domestic issues. There is a need to get beyond Brexit and focus very hard between now and the end of the parliament on the domestic agenda.“It seems odd to say it now, but the next election will not be decided on Brexit. People will be looking at other things, and it’s absolutely the case that a Conservative offering needs to say how a competitive, enterprise economy can give people more choice, can spread prosperity, instead of state controlled centralised economics.“It’s an eternal argument, and Labour this past week has set out a story which is to the left of where it has been for a long time. We have to have that argument with Labour – and not continue to have arguments about Brexit with ourselves.”In Liverpool, Mr Corbyn struck out at “greed is good” capitalism, as he branded his party’s left-wing agenda the “new common sense” to overturn decades of economic orthodoxy.We have to have that argument with Labour – and not continue to have arguments about Brexit with ourselvesPolicies included nationalisation, collective pay bargaining, a renters union for people struggling against rising costs, compulsory share ownership for workers and an expansion in free childcare.&nbspAsked whether it was going to be possible for the Tories to match this&nbspin Birmingham, Mr Green said: “I’m sure it will be the first step this week, it needs to be possible. And that isn’t where a bright future lies for the UK.”Tories take aim at May ahead of party conference: ‘Stuck in the past’Everything you need to know about the Conservative Party ConferenceMay told to end austerity by senior Conservative on eve of conferenceIf May offered a final say on Brexit, she would win another electionGeorge Freeman, former head of Ms May’s policy board, is among those attempting to make the Conservatives realise the danger the party is in.The MP for Mid Norfolk, who runs the annual Big Tent Ideas Festival to drum up new thinking, said: “’All of us on the centre right need to wake up and smell the coffee.“We are living through a 1975, 1945 or 1905 moment, when an old order passes and a new order emerges. The crash, QE inflation and asset boom, public sector austerity and Brexit mean the old political rules no longer apply. &nbsp“Unless we recognise and respect the very real grievances Corbyn is tapping into and set out bold Conservative solutions, the tide will continue to turn against us.”Many Tories appear to be impressed by the way&nbspLabour has packaged its policy agenda, taking what they&nbspbelieve&nbspto be outdated socialist ideas and making them appear relevant in the modern world.&nbspMr Freeman said: “This week Labour moved dangerously close to looking&nbsplike a credible government-in-waiting. While their policies of renationalisation, raids on company shareholder registers and massive extra debt and tax would be disastrous, they have successfully recognised the changed mood of the country.“We urgently need to set out the Conservative alternative.”The Independent spoke to two other cabinet ministers who backed Mr Freeman’s warning about the need for an overhaul of the party’s policy agenda and agreed that the Corbyn threat is now tangible.Corbyn offers Brexit truce with May if her final deal is ‘sensible’Will Tanner was one of Ms May’s top aides until he left No 10 to set up and run the free-market think tank Onward, which enjoys the ear of senior Tory figures.He said he had been surprised&nbspby the coherence of the Labour leader’s overall message in Liverpool, adding: “It felt like Jeremy Corbyn has actually managed to not only develop a relatively coherent agenda, but also found a language and narrative in which to cloak it, which softens lots of the edges that people are most worried about.“That potentially makes it far more popular than it might otherwise be in terms of talking about things in ways that we know resonate with voters.”He pointed as an example of his analysis to shadow chancellor John McDonnell’s plan to enforce “inclusive share ownership funds” for workers, which he argued was a repackaging of the old socialist idea of “requisitioning profits”.But he said the Conservative Party faced major challenges in attempting to counter the Corbyn push.&nbspKeir Starmer says there should be a general election if Theresa May’s deal is voted down“The question at the moment is one of unity,” he said.“There are multiple strands of thinking going on within Conservatism right now and there isn’t the coherence within the Conservative Party that we saw in Labour’s message.“The danger is that ergent views of what Conservatism stands for muddies the message, dilutes the brand and therefore becomes much less attractive to people.”But there was little real hope from MPs that much would be done during the conference starting on Sunday.Former minister and prominent Tory thinker Nick Boles MP said: “We clearly do have a job to do, but it won’t happen next week. We need to get Brexit out of the way first.”Another serving minister said it was “inevitable” that the entire conference would be “utterly consumed with Brexit”.Meanwhile, another prominent backbencher said: “There might be interesting conversations going on in rooms here and there, but the overall context and unavoidable message will be about Brexit. Boris Johnson will see to that.”Talks of an imminent challenge to the prime minister have receded in recent weeks, with a critical European summit following with days of the Conservative conference.But Ms May’s days are still seen as numbered, with one MP from the moderate centre of the parliamentary party echoing comments made by several that, “yes, of course we need a totally new policy platform, but the idea it will emerge this week is a bit too hopeful.“Frankly we need a change in leader as well. your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsThe Office for National Statistics judges that investment by companies fell by 0.7 per cent in the three months to June, following a contraction of 0.5 per cent in the first quarterClick to followThe IndependentBusiness investment fell again in the second quarter of 2018, suggesting that uncertainty over Brexit is hitting firms’ spending.The Office for National Statistics (ONS)&nbspestimated on Friday&nbspthat investment by companies fell by 0.7 per cent in the three months to June, following a contraction of 0.5 per cent in the first quarter.The data follows a finding by the Bank of England’s network of regional agents that firms are putting investment on hold, or erting it abroad, due to fears about new trade frictions with the European Union.However, the Bank’s governor&nbspMark Carney&nbsphas also said that investment by firms could pick up strongly if political progress is made towards a withdrawal deal with the EU.The real reasons behind collapse of UK economic growth to 6-year lowOverall GDP growth was judged by the ONS to have been 0.4 per cent in the second quarter.But its estimate for growth in the first quarter was cut from 0.2 per cent to 0.1 per cent.The agency said this downgrade was due to a more accurate view of the performance of the construction sector based on VAT receipts.Builders were severely hit by the Beast from the East&nbspsnowstorms in February and March.The annual GDP growth rate for Q2 has been revised down from 1.3 per cent to 1.2 per cent.The latest official estimate of the fall in construction output in Q1Thanks to the Q1 revision, the ONS said growth in the first half of 2018 was the weakest since the second half of 2011.“Although it has picked up a little from a slow start to the year, underlying economic growth remains persistently below the long-term average,” said Rob Kent-Smith of the ONS.“The latest business investment data shows growth weakening for the fourth quarter in a row.”The ONS now estimates that construction output plunged by 1.7 per cent in the first quarter, before recovering by 0.8 per cent in the second quarter.It sees manufacturing output contracting by 0.7 per cent in the second quarter, after falling 0.1 per cent in the first three months.However, services growth in the second quarter is seen as picking up to 0.6 per cent, from 0.3 per cent previously.Squeezed by Brexit uncertaintyThe ONS also reported that the UK current account deficit widened to 3.9 per cent in the second quarter, as export values fell by 0.1 per cent and imports grew by 1.6 per cent.Net trade was a drag on growth for the second successive quarter, despite hopes that the fall in sterling would support manufacturing exports.GDP per capita grew by 0.2 per cent in the second quarter, after falling 0.1 per cent in the first.The aggregate saving ratio of the household sector was up slightly to 3.9 per cent, but still close to a record low.Once household investment spending is included, the sector was a net borrower for the seventh consecutive quarter.Some economists have warned that such a low saving ratio&nbspmay not be sustainable.The Bank of England in August forecast GDP growth of 1.4 per cent in 2018, down from 1.7 per cent last year.It expects a pickup to 1.8 per cent in 2019, although this is predicated on a “smooth” Brexit.But sterling has been under pressure in recent weeks as progress towards an agreement with the EU has stalled and the prime minister’s Chequers plan was rejected by EU leaders in Salzburg title: unilever netherlands move legal general vote dutch incorporation lg vote
story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsThe consumer goods giant wants to move because Dutch laws offer more comprehensive protections against hostile takeoversClick to followThe IndependentLegal &amp General, one of Europe’s largest asset managers, will be voting against Unilever’s “Marmite” plan to shut up shop in Britain and move to the Netherlands. &nbspThe British-Dutch consumer goods giant, which is known for owning hundreds of brands including Dove, Ben &amp Jerry’s and Knorr, announced its intentions to leave the UK earlier this year, with the aim of unifying its corporate structure with a single HQ in Rotterdam. &nbspL&ampG explained their rather unusual step of declaring their voting intention weeks ahead of Unilever’s shareholder meeting next month by citing “significant client enquiries” about the company’s plans to move away from London. &nbspSacha Sadan, director of corporate governance at Legal &amp General Investment Management (LGIM), said: “We do not believe Unilever has made a compelling case for many PLC shareholders to support the recommendation in favour of Dutch incorporation. Therefore, we intend to vote against Unilever’s proposed resolution.”Investors should not despair – Unilever can still stay in the FTSE 100Unilever hikes idend and announces €6bn share buy-backLondon may be losing Unilever’s HQ but it must not lose its sharesUnilever, which has been based in Britain for almost a century, reviewed its dual-headed corporate structure in the aftermath of an attempted $143bn takeover from Kraft Heinz last year, as Dutch laws offer more comprehensive protections against hostile takeovers. Bosses have since tried to convince investors that their proposed Dutch incorporation will “create a simpler, more agile and more focused company”.Unilever needs at least 75 per cent of votes of London-listed shareholders in order to get the green light for an exodus from the capital.Mr Sadan added: “As a supportive shareholder in Unilever for more than 25 years, we have engaged with the company on a number of issues including its decision to unify its corporate structure. &nbspWe asked the company to ensure that any approach they take safeguards the ability of our clients to maintain their investment and benefit from Unilever’s continued success.”LGIM’s decision to vote against the relocation plans of the UK’s third largest company mirrors the opposition expressed by other shareholders, including Brewin Dolphin, Lindsell Train and Columbia Threadneedle.Nicla Di Palma, equity analyst at Brewin Dolphin, said: “We aren’t convinced that the move will realise tangible benefits for shareholders and plan to vote against.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: Germany Angela Merkel CDU Christian Democratic Union politics
story: The German Chancellor, now in her third term, had been urged to step down from her role in the CDU amid plunging approval ratings.The 64-year-old engaged her critics yesterday after saying she would run for re-election at the party congress in December.Alexander Mitsch, a senior figure on the CDU's conservative wing, said Mrs Merkel should quit for the sake of the party and country.He said: It would be better in the interest of the CDU and Germany if it paves the way for the much-needed renewal of personnel.                MERKEL ON BRINK: Chancellor under pressure from business leaders                Merkel faces calls or resignation but she still has one EU fanMrs Merkel should draw the consequences of the mistakes made by her, especially in the asylum policy, and the resulting poor poll numbers.This would be an opportunity to re-integrate the party's conservative and pro-business wing.But Ralph Brinkhaus, the head of the CDU and Christian Social Union (CSU) in the German parliament, threw his weight behind Mrs Merkel.He said: I assume that she will compete, and I would endorse that, because a head of government also needs the backing of the party.Angela Merkel is under growing pressure to quit as CDU leader (Image: EPA)Mr Brinkhaus replaced Volker Kauder, a long-standing ally of Angela Merkel, in the post earlier this week after a party vote.The shock poll dealt a further blow to the Chancellor's waning authority, as she struggles to unite Germany's coalition.Social Democratic politician Thomas Oppermann said the move was an uprising against Merkel.Alexander Graf Lambsdorff, from Germany's Free Democratic Party, said it was the beginning of the end of the grand coalition.                German leader Angela Merkel issues apology as coalition hit by crisis                Merkel DEFEATED: German chancellor hit by HUGE UPRISING The German Chancellor's approval ratings have plunged in recent months (Image: )Daniel Guenther, the premier of northern state Schleswig Holstein, added: The vote shows a desire for renewal.There was clearly a certain discontent over national politics.And a CDU adviser said: Kauder was the first domino to fall, but there might well be more. This could be just the start.I can imagine the entire senior party leadership coming under pressure to resign, and that includes Merkel.

title: Chequers has backing from the Brexiteers
story: Transport Secretary Chris Grayling on board a train at Waterloo station in London (Image: PA WirePA Images)His comments follow reports that some within the Cabinet are pushing Mrs May to back a Canada-style deal, if the EU continues to reject the Chequers proposals.&nbspSince walking out of the Cabinet in protest at Mrs May&rsquos Brexit plans, Mr Johnson and Mr Davis have both called for &ldquoSuper Canada deals.&nbspMr Grayling said: &ldquoMost of the Brexiteers are still in the Cabinet. &ldquoDavid Davis and Boris Johnson chose not to stay but the rest of us have backed the proposal.&nbsp                Brexit COUNTDOWN: The UK&rsquos three options left if Chequers IS chucked                Brexit chaos: David Davis explains WHY May has FAILED to make a suc...But, he went on, it is now &ldquofor the EU to come back to us with their plans. &ldquoThe lesson of the last week is, &lsquoOK you don&rsquot like Chequers, what are you proposing?&rsquo &nbspHe added: &ldquoMy message to Sunday Express readers is, we have to do two things.&nbsp&ldquoWe have to fulfil the result of the referendum... We have got to protect the union that is the UK and be really robust with the EU about not accepting the concept they want: a border between Northern Ireland and Great Britain.&nbspHe added: &ldquoI believe the Chequers proposal is a credible way of doing that and we have heard nothing else credible from the other side.&nbsp&ldquoSaying that we are going to have the same product specifications as are in the rest of the EU is just what is going to happen, because companies are not going to make a different product for the UK and France.&nbsp&ldquoBut does this take back control of our borders? Yes. Does it take back control of agriculture and fisheries? Yes.&nbsp&ldquoWhat the Chequers proposal does is allow the smooth flow of trade across borders and provides protection for the car manufacturers and others based in the UK, without compromising the principles of the referendum.&nbspHe said that Mrs May could never accept a separate customs regime for Northern Ireland.&nbspBut he suggested that Jeremy Corbyn could sign up to such a proposal.&nbsp&ldquoThe Labour leader is a dangerous politician who would break up the United Kingdom, he said.&nbsp&ldquoHe is someone who would countenance demilitarising the United Kingdom.&nbsp                'Britons want a proper Brexit!' Tory MP vows to back Super-Canada dealMrs May will try to sell her Brexit vision to the party&rsquos grassroots today (Image: James GourleyREXShutterstock&#8232)Mr Grayling also called on the EU to match Mrs May&rsquos pledge to guarantee the rights of all EU citizens who live in the UK even if we leave the bloc without an agreement.&nbspMr Grayling said: &ldquoI would hope and expect the EU do the same.&nbspMrs May will try to sell her Brexit vision to the party&rsquos grassroots today.&nbspShe will speak to the Conservative national convention, where she is expected to face tough questions over her Brexit plans.&nbspSources denied Mrs May had decided to attend the event following calls to defend her policy to her party.&nbsp

title: Labour and union leaders back plans to bring in four day week
story: Union leaders have already backed the case for a four-day working week (Image: Ezra BaileyGetty Images)Supporters say that advances in technology have made the traditional five-day week outdated and claim that new ways of working should allow staff more time off to spend on hobbies and with loved ones.&nbspBut critics have claimed that a four-day week would be dangerous and could hurt the economy.Union leaders have already backed the case for a four-day working week.&nbspTUC boss Frances O&rsquoGrady said that bosses and shareholders &ldquomust not be allowed to hoover up all the gains from new tech.&nbsp                Theresa May&rsquos plan to CRUSH Labour revealed But even the unions have suggested that the change in working patterns could take until 2100 to achieve.&nbspA Labour insider said that the party was &ldquoconsidering the idea and that it could come forward with more details this autumn.&nbspLast year the Green Party was mocked when it backed a four-day week.&nbspResearch from the International Monetary Fund suggests that the 35-hour week in France had cut employment and not made workers happier.&nbsp&#9679&nbspModerate Labour MP Chris Leslie has hit back after his local party voted that they had no confidence in him.He said: &ldquoIf the party pushes away people like me on the centre Left for voicing different opinions to the leadership, then that says more about the direction of Labour than it does about me.

title: Brexit EU secret document truth British public
story: France’s Emmanuel Macron uses German crisis to call for EU integration                Three EU countries that face HUGE contribution hikes after BrexitThe unknown author &ndash a senior civil servant &ndash correctly predicted the then European Economic Community (the EEC effectively became the EU in 1993) was headed for economic, monetary and fiscal union, with a common foreign and defence policy, which would constitute the greatest surrender of Britain&rsquos national sovereignty since 1066.He went on to say &ldquoCommunity law would take precedence over our own courts and that ever more power would pass away from Parliament to the bureaucratic system centred in Brussels.The author even accurately asserts that the increased role of Brussels in the lives of the British people would lead to a &ldquopopular feeling of alienation from Government.But shockingly politicians were advised &ldquonot to exacerbate public concern by attributing unpopular measures&hellip to the remote and unmanageable workings of the Community.&nbspPrime Minister Edward Heath kept quiet about the findings in the early 70s (Image: )They were told to preserve the impression that the British Government was still calling the shots rather than an unelected body of foreign politicians &ndash and that the ruse would last &ldquofor this century at least &ndash by which time Britain would be so completely chained to Brussels it would be impossible to leave.Document FCO301048, which has now been declassified under the 30-year rule, still shocks and angers Brexiteers.Annabelle Sanderson, a Brexit expert and former advisor to Nigel Farage said: &ldquoDespite all the claims from politicians of many parties that the EU was not about becoming a central state this 1971 document shows that is exactly what the plan was.&nbsp&ldquoArch Remoaners from Labour, Lib Dems and the Tories need to check this out and ask themselves why they are MPs if they don&rsquot actually want Westminster to be in charge of this country.&ldquoWe voted for Brexit what needs to happen is a proper clean break from Brussels so we can once again become a sovereign nation with money being spent in this country on services we need and have Parliament and courts making and ruling on the laws.Document FCO301048 still shocks and angers Brexiteers (Image: )The writer and journalist Christopher Booker, one of the founders of the satirical magazine Private Eye, said: &ldquoHere was a civil servant advising that our politicians should connive in concealing what Heath was letting us in for, not least in hiding the extent to which Britain would no longer be a democratic country but one essentially governed by unelected and unaccountable officials.&ldquoOne way to create an illusion that this system was still democratic, this anonymous mandarin suggested, would be to give people the chance to vote for new representatives at European, regional and local levels.&nbsp&ldquoA few years later, we saw the creation of an elected European Parliament &ndash as we see today a craze for introducing elected mayors, as meaningless local figureheads.The pro-Europe Sir Edward Heath was leader of the Conservative Party from 1965 to 1975.&nbspHe died in 2005.In 2015 he was named as part of Wiltshire Police&rsquos Operation Conifer investigation into historical child sex abuse.Detectives said if alive &ndash he would have been 101 &ndash he would have been interviewed under caution over seven claims, including the alleged rape of an 11-year-old, but that no inference of guilt should be drawn from this.Operation Conifer was closed earlier this year after officers found no corroborating evidence of any sexual abuse by Sir Edward and no evidence of a conspiracy.Brexit fund GUARANTEED: politician from a lower middle-class family, was born in Broadstairs, Kent.He served though the Second World War in the Royal Artillery, rising to rank of Lieutenant-Colonel.Although he said he had never killed anyone he was part of the Normandy Landings in 1944 and wrote extensively of the damage his gunners inflicted on the German occupying forces.In September 1945 he also commanded a firing squad that executed a Polish soldier convicted of rape and murder.He was made a Knight of the Garter on 23 April 1992 and became Sir Edward Heath.

story: The Duchess of Cambridge, who welcomed Louis into the world in April, is kick-starting her return as a working royal by visiting the Sayers Croft Forest School and the Wildlife Garden at Paddington Recreation Ground, London, on Tuesday.After that, the duchess, also mother to Prince George, five, and Princess Charlotte, three, will make an appearance at a charity event for World Mental Health Day the week after, as well as the much-anticipated wedding of Princess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank in Windsor days after.The 36-year-old&rsquos schedule in the weeks to come remains busier than it was when she returned to royal duties after having Prince George and Princess Charlotte.When George was born, Kate was out of the public eye for six weeks, while with Charlotte, she was not seen on royal duty for at least two months.                We must spend more on research into dementia - EXPRESS COMMENTHer maternity leave with Louis was also notably longer compared to the ones she took with George and Charlotte, both of which having been less than the usual nine months.Royal fans were left surprised when Kate also undertook more engagements throughout her most recent stint of maternity leave.Though examples such as attending celebrations to mark the Centenary of Royal Air Force in July and the Trooping the Colour celebration the month before were not official duties, it saw her out and about at events regardless.She also attended Wimbledon and Prince Harry&rsquos wedding to former Suits actress Meghan Markle in May, a bash that saw the Duchess of Cambridge dazzle more than 100,000 well-wishers just one month after giving birth to Louis.When George was born, Kate was out of the public eye for six weeks, (Image: )The 36-year-old&rsquos schedule in the weeks to come remains busier than it was  after having George (Image: )This break of tradition was something the duchess did not to after giving birth to Prince George in 2013 and Princess Charlotte in 2015.Kate and William are known for their hands on style of parenting, and try to keep their young ones out of the spotlight when they can to ensure their children have as much of a normal upbringing as possible.The family-of-five are now residing at their country home, Anmer hall, in Norfolk where George and Charlotte spent their early beginnings.Kate has constantly expressed her joy in spending time with her children, and said she loves taking part in activities with George and Charlotte, such as making pizza dough and playing outside.

title: brexit news irish border dr ray bassett northern ireland hard border
story: Dr Ray Bassett warned Dublin it must start looking out for Ireland&rsquos own interests rather than attempting to score points with Brussels by toeing the EU&rsquos line over the frontier.The former ambassador acknowledged that no technological solution which can completely avoid the need for border infrastructure currently exists, but insisted &ldquogoodwill and common sense between the neighbouring nations &ldquoshould allow for a workable solution.And he urged Leo Varadkar&rsquos government to come to its senses and &ldquorealise that its deep connections with its neighbour, the United Kingdom, are more valuable than temporary plaudits from Brussels.The issue of how to avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic has become the last major hurdle negotiators need to overcome to secure a Brexit deal.                Arlene Foster applauds Theresa May for 'STANDING FIRM' against EUBrussels has put forward two options but Theresa May has rejected both, warning the first would effectively cut Northern Ireland off from the rest of the UK and the other would &ldquomake a mockery of the decision to leave the EU.The Prime Minister warned last week that if the bloc is not willing to budge in its demands and agree on a compromise, Britain could leave with no deal.But Dr Bassett said &ldquothere is no need for the Irish border question either to derail the EUUK Brexit discussions or to determine the overall agreement.And he insisted a solution has not been reached purely because of political, not practical reasons.Brexit news: The Irish border issue is political, not practical, Dr Ray Bassett said (Image:  IMAGES)Dr Bassett worked for Ireland's Department of Foreign Affairs for 39 years (Image: NC)Irish leader Leo Varadkar needs to put Ireland's interests first, Dr Bassett said (Image: PA)                Brexit news: Irish border could be solved with THIS tech says expertIn a new paper on the Irish border question published by the Politeia think-tank, Dr Bassett said: &ldquoThe border question has been used by elements within the Remain camp to try and block the UK&rsquos departure from the EU.&ldquoIt is certainly not in the long-term interest of Ireland to be used in this cynical manner.&ldquoWhile there is no comparable international example that can be readily used to solve the issue, goodwill and common sense should allow for a workable solution.&ldquoIt could be based on major exemptions for small companies and purely local trade, as well as agricultural and food products. The remaining trade could be monitored and operated on a trusted trader system.&ldquoUnder these arrangements, there would be no need for any new physical infrastructure on the border.&ldquoThe danger is that politics, not practicalities, will get in the way.Remain supporters in Northern Ireland are staunchly opposed to a hard border (Image:  IMAGES)Dr Bassett served in Ireland&rsquos Department of Foreign Affairs for 39 years during which time he was involved in the Good Friday Agreement negotiations.He has since become an outspoken critic of the Irish government&rsquos approach to Brexit.Dr Bassett said an exit deal which allows for frictionless trade between the UK and Ireland is &ldquovital for Irish interests.He said half of Ireland&rsquos beef is purchased by Britain with firms in the UK also buying between 40 and 50 percent of exports from Irish small and medium-sized businesses.Theresa May has rejected the EU's options for the Irish border (Image:  IMAGES)He said: &ldquoHence, it is overwhelmingly in Ireland&rsquos interest that the UK and the EU agree to friction-free arrangements across a wide range of areas.&ldquoRationally, Ireland should be the UK&rsquos strongest ally inside the EU, pressing for the best possible terms and a successful Brexit.The former diplomat also questioned Ireland&rsquos &ldquoslavish devotion to the EU.He predicted his home country will see a &ldquogrowing disenchantment with Brussels as the bloc attempts to move towards a &ldquoUnited States of Europe.He added: &ldquoThe whole sustainability of the European Union, as presently constituted, is in serious long-term doubt.&ldquoIreland needs to be on the right side of these historical developments.

title: Brexit news UK Labour Party Jeremy Corbyn Keir Starmer Kate Hoey Hilary Benn EU
story: Jeremy Corbyn said at the Labour Party conference in Liverpool this week that MPs would vote down any Chequers based Brexit plan and called for the Prime Minister to change her blueprint if she wanted support from Labour.Theresa May has claimed negotiations are at an &ldquoimpasse and is defiantly standing by her controversial Chequers plan which has received criticism from within her party, and from EU leaders at Salzburg.At the conference in Liverpool, Labour Party frontbenchers insisted that they wanted a general election instead of a second Brexit vote, but added all options were still &ldquoon the table should Mrs May&rsquos plan not get through the House of Commons.Shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer said &ldquonobody is ruling out Remain as an option should there be another referendum on Britain&rsquos relationship with the EU, and claimed Labour would only back a deal that met all of the party&rsquos six tests.                Labour's Caroline Flint RIPS into colleagues backing People's Vote                Councillor mocks attempted Remain 'TAKEOVER' for new Brexit voteSpeaking exclusively with Express, Labour Party MP for Don Valley, Caroline Flint clearly outlined why the party could not back another referendum on leaving the EU.She said: &ldquoWe did have a people&rsquos vote in 2016, and I don&rsquot feel any sense that people have changed their minds. They want us to get on with it. The problem with a second referendum is that it will just reopen, I think, all the isions that emerged in 2016.&ldquoWhat I want to see is a reasonable deal that allows us to get on with things, but also concentrate on some of those massive issues that people had around the country where they voted Leave.&ldquoCommunities like Doncaster and&nbspelsewhere&nbspdidn&rsquot feel they were getting a better share of the national wealth that they were entitled to. In all this debate, that isn&rsquot being discussed as much as it should be.Speaking alongside Ms Flint at a fringe meeting on Tuesday evening, Labour peer Lord Adonis described himself as a &ldquohardline&nbspRemainer and a &ldquodemocrat before calling for a People&rsquos Vote.He said: &ldquoThe people cannot betray the people - let&rsquos understand this. The idea the answer to a problem of democracy is no more democracy - we don&rsquot do that with elections. When we lose an election we don&rsquot say, &lsquooh well we are not having any more of those, we lost that, we are giving up&rsquo. What we do is we carry on arguing.Leading Brexit supporter and Labour MP for Vauxhall, Kate Hoey, was adamant that pro-Remain MPs in the Labour Party were &ldquonot going to get a People&rsquos Vote at the end of Brexit negotiations with the European Union.Ms Hoey also warned that it would be nearly impossible for there to be another general election, which Labour frontbenchers were demanding. She said: &ldquoIt&rsquos going to be very difficult to have a general election, even if nobody wants any deal the Prime Minister brings back with, because of the fixed term parliament.&ldquoI think a lot of MPs who might say publicly they might like a general election, but actually, in&nbsppractice&nbspdo they really want it, on both sides?&ldquoThe electorate at the moment is very volatile and no-one can take for granted&nbspthe electorate's vote&nbspand how they are going to vote no matter what they did in the past.Brexit news: Labour MP's discussed whether there should be a People's Vote at conference (Image: EXPRESS&bull)British entrepreneur John Mills commented on whether the People&rsquos Vote was picking up &ldquomomentum. Mr Mills claimed support was rising, but only in London and Canterbury, and not in&nbspWales, the Midlands and the north of England.He said: &ldquoI think for the Labour Party to start supporting having a second referendum is&nbspa very&nbspdangerous course of action and I think the leadership of the Labour Party realise this.Chair of the Brexit select committee, Hilary Benn, admitted that it was &ldquohard to see a majority of MPs coming out to back&nbspa second&nbspvote.He said: &ldquoI don&rsquot know, I think at the moment it&rsquos hard to see a majority for that emerging in the House of Commons. We&rsquove got a long way to go in this process, ironically in a short amount of time.He added: &ldquoI think the best way to get a sensible Brexit negotiated is to have a change of Government. Because if the Prime Minister has boxed herself in and has nowhere to go now&hellipwe would have a very different kind of Brexit if a Labour Government was elected.The prospect of a change of leadership was echoed by Labour&rsquos shadow justice secretary Richard Burgon who said a general election is a real possibility.He said: &ldquoIt&rsquos not in Labour&rsquos gift to call for a general election but I think a general election is a real possibility and that&rsquos our preference. If a Labour Government is elected in that early general election then what we&rsquoll do is bring the country together.&ldquoAccept and respect the referendum and secure a Brexit that meets the six tests that Keir Starmer has set out.Labour&rsquos shadow communities and local government secretary, Andrew Gwynne, added that Labour did not want to &ldquoreopen the 2016 referendum result as he called for a general election.Mr Gwynne also claimed the Government had &ldquofailed miserably in negotiations with the EU.The Mayor of Greater Manchester, Andy Burnham made clear the Brexit result must be &ldquorespected, claiming that the best outcome would be a &ldquodeal.Mr Burnham added that there could only be a People&rsquos Vote if &ldquofurther down the line a no deal is looking like a possible scenario and would only be acceptable as a &ldquolast resort.However, Labour MP for Exeter Ben Bradshaw claimed that &ldquopeople&rsquos minds are changing as they see the reality of Brexit &ndash particularly the reality of the prospect of a no deal Brexit.He added: &ldquoThe Government has completely failed to deliver Brexit in a competent way and we are facing the prospect of either a very bad deal or no deal at all which would be catastrophic for our economy.Labour MP Caroline Flint explained why the party should not back a People's Vote (Image: EXPRESS)&ldquoAnd I think in those circumstances, parliamentarians, whatever their political colour, are going to do what they know is in the best interests of their constituents. If the prospect of the choice is between a crash out no deal scenario and another referendum, I think that&rsquos what they would go for.Labour MP for Blackley and Broughton, Graham Stringer, said he did not think there was a majority in the House of Commons for a second referendum on leaving the EU.Mr Stringer said the arguments of those calling for a second referendum did not &ldquostack up. He said: &ldquoI don&rsquot think there will be a second referendum, nor should there be.Ronnie Campbell, Labour MP for Blyth Valley, added that the Labour Party needed to be &ldquovery careful about&nbspa second&nbspvote on Europe.He said: &ldquoIf they are saying it is a vote for a no deal, that might be a different matter, because a no deal, we don&rsquot know what a no deal could look like, we could go off an oblivion.&ldquoBut, not on Europe. We have had that referendum. We are leaving Europe. We have got to leave on the best terms possible. And if the Tories can&rsquot do it, there is a Labour Government there waiting to be in.Kent Labour Councillor Brendan Chilton claimed that Leave would win any future Brexit vote by a bigger majority but warned the party about &ldquoalienating working-class voters from the Labour Party.Prominent Labour politicians have joined calls for a People&rsquos Vote after Brexit negotiations, including the London Mayor Sadiq Khan.Addressing the conference on Wednesday, Mr Corbyn insisted Labour would not overturn Brexit but questioned the conduct of the May Government during the negotiations with Brussels.Mr Corbyn said: &ldquoLabour respects the decision of the British people in the referendum but no one can respect the conduct of the government since that vote took place.As it stands, Labour will vote against the Chequers plan or whatever is left of it and oppose leaving the EU with no deal. And it is inconceivable that we should crash out of Europe with no deal &ndash that would be a national disaster.&ldquoThat is why if Parliament votes down a Tory deal or the government fails to reach any deal at all we would press for a general election. Failing that, all options are on the table. Brexit is about the future of our country and our vital interests.Additional reporting by Jodie Packwood in Liverpool.

School of Anthropology and Conservation (SAC) stated the EU policies are favouring larger boats and richer owners.As a result, smaller fleets and iniduals were pushed out of their livelihood.Professor Douglas MacMillan, one of the researchers taking part in the study, said the CFP focuses too much on fish stock conservation and has no meaningful policy regulations to ensure that quotas for Eurosceptic claims he's 'yet again' the 'only Brexiteer on a BBC panelSpeaking earlier in the show, the Belgian journalist also claimed Theresa May and the European Union already have a deal in their &ldquopockets.He said: &ldquoI think Theresa May is in a strong position. There will be a deal because&nbspotherwise,&nbspit will be a disaster.When political commentator Alex Deane later called Mr Roche a &ldquoBrexiteer on-air, the Belgian journalist replied by claiming he was a &ldquoRemainer who believes that &ldquoBrexit will happen.Theresa May claimed Brexit negotiations with the European Union were at an &ldquoimpasse after her Chequers agreement was dealt a series of blows by EU leaders following Salzburg.Despite this, Mrs May has stuck by her blueprint, claiming the options remaining for the UK include either her Chequers plan or a Brexit no deal.Speaking ahead of the Conservative Party conference, the Prime Minister has urged ministers to get behind her Chequers agreement.She said: &ldquoThe theme of Conservative party conference this year is&nbspopportunity. Two years on from the referendum, we&rsquove made progress in the Brexit negotiations at the same time as improving life for people here at home.Brexit news: Marc Roche claimed finalising the Brexit deal will be 'easy' (Image: BBC)But we&rsquore now at a crucial moment. The right deal is close &ndash and with it the opportunity to make life better for ordinary working people.So at this Conference, we will be setting out how we will provide&nbspopportunity&nbspfor all &ndash a stronger, fairer country with real opportunity for people who work hard and do the right thing.Former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, who quit from the cabinet earlier this year because of Mrs May&rsquos Chequers plan, has outlined his own solution to Brexit negotiations.Mr Johnson has urged the Government to &ldquochuck Chequers and &ldquostop wasting time on a solution that can never be in the long-term interests of this country.

story: M27 CLOSED: Traffic to be sent on 58 mile ersion for bridge repair (Image: HIGHWAYS ENGLAND)Highways England will close the M27 tonight between junctions 3 and 4 at Romsey and Southampton for a &pound19million bridge repair.The closure begins at 9pm tonight and doesn&rsquot end until 5am on Monday morning.The travel chaos has been described as &ldquothe biggest traffic ersion ever in the country by Hampshire&rsquos fire and rescue service.Westbound drivers will be sent on a hellish ersion to Andover on the A303, before heading all the way to Salisbury and back to Southampton on the A34.                Swan causes tailback on M27 after crash landing                Postcard from Largs arrives in Southampton &ndash after 35 yearsSmaller vehicles will be able to use more local and rural roads, but heavy goods vehicles will have to drive 58 miles before re-joining the motorway.It will cost lorry drivers an extra &pound35 in fuel, according to the Road Haulage Association.A spokesman for the RHA said: &ldquoAt a time when a typical hauliers' profit margins are one to two per cent, the impact of this ersion will hit hard.&ldquoDelivery times will also be affected and many drivers will be forced to park up to take statutory rest breaks on the route, with some even needing to park up overnight.The M27 ersion map (Image: HIGHWAYS ENGLAND)The local ersion map after the M27 is closed (Image: HIGHWAYS ENGLAND)&ldquoIt is also inevitable that drivers will be tempted to use other shorter routes, some of which may not be suitable for lorries.And the traffic hell won&rsquot just affect motorists this weekend, with two more weekends of closures to follow in the next 12 months.Closures will also take place next year between April 26 and 29 and October 18 and 21 2019.Highways England is rushing to fix the A3057 Romsey Road Bridge over the motorway after &ldquosevere cracks were spotted on the structure used by thousands of vehicles every day.Route sponsor John Henderson said: &ldquoCompleting these key phases of work at the weekend means that restrictions can be kept to a minimum at other, busier, times and we have chosen ersions that are the most suitable for the type and volume of traffic that usually uses the M27.

story: Bidfood needs assurances before Christmas otherwise it will have no choice but to stockpile food (Image: )Bidfood UK is holding crunch talks with customers fearing links to its European producers could be severely impacted if Britain leaves the EU without a deal.It needs assurances before Christmas otherwise it will have no choice but to stockpile food.Two-thirds of Bidfood UK&rsquos 15,000 food items are sourced in the UK but Bidfood UK chief executive Andrew Selley said a hard Brexit would mean shortages of EU products including chips from Belgium, pasta and olive oil from Italy and meat from eastern Europe.Mr Selley said: &ldquoWe&rsquore looking at where we could switch to different products that are UK sourced.                Brexiteer brands Labour MP 'RIDICULOUS' over no deal stockpiling claim                'There is no better Brexit!' Patrick Kielty blasts Boris Johnson plan&ldquoIn a partnership approach with customers, we&rsquore working on menu development, to say: &lsquoThis product may not be available. A lot of meat products like chicken in the UK come from Holland an Poland, so could you look at more non-meat products, vegan or vegetarian options?&rsquo.Bidfood UK uses 1,000 trucks to make 12,000 deliveries from 24,000 depots week.The firm is one of a growing number that fear a collapse of the pound could end up pushing their costs up higher.Many similar companies also fear they could face a shortage of EU workers in the event of a hard Brexit and delays at British ports could hold up deliveries and ruin stock.Mr Selley said unless there was a breakthrough before Christmas, his firm would be forced to ship in extra supplies.He said: &ldquoWe&rsquod need safety stocks in for some of those items if we felt it was going to be a hard Brexit and we felt those border delays would happen.A survey this week by the Chartered Institute of Procurement and Supply said just one in 10 UK firms fear bankruptcy as a result of as a result of a no-deal Brexit that would result in port delays by even just one hour.Today, an MP warned Theresa May&rsquos premiership could be in trouble after former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson released his own six-point Brexit plan yesterday, which had emerged after the failure of her own Chequers plan when presented to Brussels.                Tory Brexiteer claims overturning Brexit would be like 'LOSING A WAR'Brexiteer MP Bernard Jenkin said: &ldquo&ldquoThe problem for the Prime Minister is that she has hitched herself to the wrong policy.&rsquoHe then blasted the Government for &ldquoswallowing Project Fear.He also said that although he would &ldquonever underestimate Mrs May, he blasted &ldquoweakly conducted negotiations and said that &ldquothe Government has never really accepted that we are going to leave the EU.The Brexit talks are currently at an impasse with the issue of how to avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic still a major hurdle which has yet to be overcome.Mrs May has insisted her Chequers proposals are the only viable plans, but Brussels last week rejected her plans for the Irish frontier.

story: An earlier trial of the proposal triggered a 14 percent increase in recycling (Image: )Conwy County Council in north Wales scrapped their initial plan to cut landfill collections to once every three weeks, which had got residents fuming when it was put into place in 2016.They have now replaced the plan with a new one that will see bin men whip around the small market town and rural areas once every four weeks.An earlier trial of the proposal triggered a 14 percent increase in recycling, which led to the council rolling the plan out this week.Officials believe the cut in bin collections will save them up to &pound400,000 annually and save them &pound600,000 in yearly fines from the Welsh government.                Plaid Cymru leader says he'll use 'EVERY MEAN POSSIBLE' to stop Brexit                'It's Labour's fault' BBC host in SHOCKING remark on Welsh Labour ruleThey also hope the change will increase their recycling rates from 64 percent to 70 percent by 2025.But residents have blasted the plan and have reported an increase in rodents, smells and flies.Tracy Hulme, from Old Colwyn, said she has to get a relative to stand on the contents of her wheelie bins in wellies to make room for more household waste from her four young children, three dogs and two cats.Fellow mum-of-four Frankie Hamlet, of Llysfaen, near Colwyn Bay, said she found a rat in her kitchen cupboard and cited the drop in bin collections as the cause.They also hope the change will increase their recycling rates from 64 percent to 70 percent (Image: )She said: &ldquoMy bin was emptied yesterday and it&rsquos already half full.&ldquoIf there&rsquos rubbish hanging around it&rsquos going to make the situation ten times worse.The council said there was no evidence that the piles of rubbish in Ms Hamlet&rsquos area would have attracted rats.A spokesman added it had received 449 reports of rats in the past 12 months, down from 659 the previous year. Rising trade in stolen wheelie binsYet reports of fly-tipping rose from 986 in the past 12 months to September 2016 to 1,093 in the following year.The change has been condemned by the Chartered Institute of Environmental Health, who said the lack of bin collections would cause a risk to public health from pests, odours and domestic waste burning.Tony Lewis, Chartered Institute of Environmental Health head of policy, said the change could work &ldquoif people stick to the rules but people don&rsquot stick to the rules.Don Milne, Conwy&rsquos Conservative cabinet member for environment, said cutting collections was &ldquoall about increasing recycling.

story: David Davis has launched a fresh scathing attack on Theresa May (Image: Getty)The former Brexit Secretary warned the Government&rsquos defeat at the summit was due to Mrs May&rsquos advisers not fully grasping the &ldquopracticalities of the negotiations.This included believing in the EU&rsquos exaggerated claims on the ongoing Northern Ireland issue, which Mr Davis describes as being utterly manageable.Speaking from his home near Hodwen, in Yorkshire, Mr Davis told the  he has always campaigned to respect the 2016 Brexit referendum with a &ldquorobust approach, unlike Downing Street.He said: &ldquoThe tendency on the part of the Whitehall advice, and the No 10 advice in particular, is to say, what&rsquos negotiable, what&rsquos achievable.                Brexit COUNTDOWN: The UK&rsquos three options left if Chequers IS chucked                Brexit no deal could see meat and chips taken OFF menu, says supplier Mr Davis claimed he tried to &ldquostrike out the &ldquonew customs partnership plan three times last year.He said: &ldquoI thought at first it was the Treasury being difficult.&ldquoIt turned out it was No 10.&ldquoThey said we&rsquove got to keep it in for &lsquonegotiability&rsquo reasons.Mr Davis said he has always campaigned to respect the result of the 2016 Brexit referendum (Image: Getty)&ldquoThat&rsquos not the way you design your policies.&ldquoYou design your policies, then sell them, then amend them if you do have to do that but not the other way around.The former Brexit Secretary insisted Downing Street made the same mistake when trying to negotiate Chequers with the EU.Making an analogy with between the EU negotiations and buying a car, he said: &ldquo&lsquoWhat would you like me to pay you?&rsquo is not the right approach to a negotiation.
