title: natasha pret final goodbye mum
story: Tanya Ednan-Laperouse was racing to get to Natasha, 15, in hospital when hubby Nadim rang to say their daughter had two minutes to live.Tanya, 51, said: “He told me, “You’ve got to say goodbye now.’“Don’t lose time. She’s going to die any minute. Say something. She might hear it. The phone is by her ear.’“I said, ‘Tashi I love you so much, darling. I’ll be with you soon. I’ll be with you.”“‘When you’ve got children, you don’t want them to be without you, do you? They haven’t flown the nest.They still need you.“I fell to the ground. I couldn’t talk, I was engulfed with grief. I knew then she was gone.’”Natasha died from a reaction to sesame seeds in a £3.45 artichoke, olive and tapenade baguette bought at a Heathrow Pret.The meal had no allergy warning on its packaging.Natasha fell ill on a British Airways flight as she, Nadim and a pal headed for a break in the south of France in July 2016. She died in hospital in Nice.At last week’s inquest coroner Sean Cummings slammed Pret for failing to alert customers to potentially fatal allergens.Pret was warned nine times about the dangers of sesame in its artisan baguettes in the year before Natasha died.Toy firm director Tanya, from Fulham, West London, said of the firm: “They screwed up, yes. Now they have the opportunity to do something good. They could lobby for a change to our labelling laws.“We know Natasha didn’t die on our watch. She died on Pret’s watch, all thanks to the absence of two little words.“If the label had listed ‘sesame seeds’ Natasha wouldn’t have touched it and she’d still be alive.“Nadim trusted Natasha knew what to look for.”For dad Nadim the moment they made that choice is replayed over and over in his mind.And the memory brings him to tears. He said: “I hate myself. I blame myself. I really love my daughter, in a way that’s like one flesh.“As a parent I’d die a thousand times, crucied, for her to live.“I spent 15 years nurturing the most precious thing in my le. As a human being, there’s nothing more important than that.“In that moment, how could it be that I failed her? I will live with that until I die, but so it is.“I’m so glad it wasn’t Tanya’s watch because I don’t think she could have taken it’.” Mum Tanya was at home when she got the call at 9.30am.She said: “Nad was crying and said, ‘Tanya you’ve got to come out here. Natasha’s not well. Something terrible has happened.’ Initially I thought, it’s not that bad, I wanted reassurance. But Nad was saying, ‘Start looking for flights. It’s really bad.’“I was praying. Please God, don’t take her from me.”As Natasha was taken to Nice hospital, Tanya raced to Stansted. She said: “The lady at check-in said, I’m sorry, the flight’s full.“I said, ‘You’ve got to get me to France, my daughter’s dying.“Then, we were told there was a delay for six hours. I was constantly crying. Then I got the call from Nad to say she was going to die within two minutes and I had to say goodbye. And I did.“I had to just sit there and wait, knowing this was all unfolding.“I couldn’t howl, scream or cry as I was surrounded by families. I got on the plane. Tears were falling the whole time.Freshly prepared items at London branches of Greggs, EAT and fast food chains Wasabi and itsu had no allergy warnings on them.Even Pret a Manger is still using the loophole, with no warnings on packets. The law says that when food is prepared onsite, ingredient labelling is not necessary.It is designed to protect small, independent stores.At the busy shops we investigated – EAT, Pret, Wasabi and itsu at Canary Wharf Shopping Mall in East London – allergy information signs were in cabinets, urging customers to ask.But at Greggs in Chrisp Street Market no signs were visible — despite assurances from chiefs that allergy signs were there.Every shop we visited failed to feature any information on packaging for food made in-house.“It’s hard to explain, but it was on the flight I felt this overwhelming sense of sympathy for Nad.That he needed my love and understanding. I knew how much he loved Natasha. I felt so much of his pain with mine.”Nadim added: “The last thing she ever said was “Daddy, Daddy, help me. I can’t breathe.” I held her and kept talking to her. Minutes later she was gone.’ Nadim, who is considering suing Pret, added: “I spent a year on the sofa. I wrote two suicide letters. I felt it was so unfair.“We haven’t touched her room. Her clothes are still on the floor.“I still look for her on the street, in public places. Adidas trainers, long dark hair in a bun. I look but she’s just lost. You don’t know how you carry on living.”Teenager Natasha Ednan-Laperouse’s death should serve as a warning of how dangerous this practice is.The law states that when food is prepared onsite, ingredients labelling is not necessary. It is designed to protect small, independent stores. But our investigation today reveals large chains have not learnt from this avoidable tragedy.Pret a Manger was warned nine times about the dangers of sesame seed in its artisan baguettes and yet it continues to sell items without allergy warnings.Now Natasha’s mother Tanya has challenged the chain to lobby for a change in our labelling laws.And, hopefully, stop other parents having to suffer such a terrible loss.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: un appy days as divided tories meet at conference
story: Well, security on the app did not stay in place, though to be fair, it was resolved swtly. "It's sorted - and in time for the conference!" Mr Lewis told me proudly.Some problems can be sorted quickly, it seems. Not Brexit, though.It is doubtful whether the Conservatives will be any more united on the PM's Chequers plan when they leave here on Wednesday than they are as they arrive.     After his 4,500-word eve-of-conference onslaught on the PM's Brexit policy in The Daily , followed up by TV interviews, Boris Johnson's "chuck Chequers" rally on Tuesday evening - hours before the PM's big conference speech - will be the box office highlight of this conference.Boris has staged these rallies at Tory conferences before. He is greeted like a rock star with the same sort of adulation Jeremy Corbyn receives at his rallies during Labour conferences.The conference slogan this year - on enormous blue banners - contains just one word: "Opportunity", with eight pledges underneath.     The order of these pledges is interesting, reflecting Tory priorities which some in the party will claim are in the wrong order.They are, in this order::: The best Brexit deal for Britain:: A long-term plan for the NHS:: A strong economy:: Improving education:: Protecting the environment:: Tackling injustices:: Global Britain:: More homes.Is building more homes, really the party's lowest priority? As  managing Boris's bombshell this week wasn't bad enough, it was reported that Mr Lewis was planning to brandish his phone and sing the praises of the app during his speech welcoming the activists at the opening of the conference on Sunday. Not true, I'm told emphatically. Probably just as well!The other Sunday highlights, during a session on Global Britain, will be speeches by the Brexiteer International Trade Secretary Liam Fox, another Brexiteer, the International Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt, followed by the new Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt.Amid all the speculation about how long Theresa May will survive as PM, Penny Mordaunt is seen by many as a potential candidate for the leadership from the Tory right. title: whos auditioning for the conservative leadership in birmingham this week
story: :: Dominic Raab - The Brexit secretary is due to speak from the main conference stage on Monday and, other than that, he is only listed to appear at one fringe event. However,  he is interested in raising his profile for a possible tilt at the leadership, Mr Raab will no doubt consider his efforts are better spent concentrating on negotiations with the EU rather than schmoozing party members in Birmingham. As one of the few prominent Leave campaigners to support Mrs May's Chequers plan, Mr Raab is having to deal with claims from hardline Brexiteers he has betrayed the cause in favour of a cabinet position. He has also been sidelined in favour of top civil servant Olly Robbins, with Mr Raab's Brexit department no longer directly responsible for negotiating the UK's orce. However,  Mr Raab does help secure a successful Brexit outcome that the Tories can end up uniting around, surely he would then become a serious leadership candidate. :: Penny Mordaunt - The international development secretary is due to speak from the main conference stage on Sunday and is also listed to speak at three fringe events. Ms Mordaunt made a name for herself during the EU referendum as a prominent member of the Vote Leave campaign. She backs the prime minister's Chequers plan by virtue of being in government, although she has been conspicuously quiet in voicing that support publicly. This has helped fuel reports she is on the verge of quitting the cabinet unless Mrs May changes tack. In her cabinet role she has led the government response to the Oxfam sex scandal, while her additional women and equalities brief has seen her generate headlines through her support for legalising abortion in Northern Ireland. She also recently became the first government minister to use sign language during a speech in the House of Commons. If the Tories wanted a third female leader in their history, the former Splash! reality TV show star might be in pole position.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2":: Theresa May? - Not many Tories give the prime minister much hope of leading the party into the next general election, which is scheduled in 2022. Could a decent conference showing begin the rehabilitation of MPs' and members' confidence in Mrs May to continue at the head of the party?

title: brexit news alan sugar should
story: NewsBrexit news: Alan Sugar should be hired to run negotiations, says The Apprentice's Claude LittnerSeries 14 of The Apprentice stars on Wednesday when the "antagonistic" candidates will travel to MaltaShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmy Sharpe20:48, 29 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/incoming/video/apprentice-2018-candidates-sarah-bryne-13305478,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Tough-talking tycoon Alan Sugar is about to start cutting aspiring business hopefuls down to size.  In the coming weeks he will decide which one of 16 young entrepreneurs will become his business partner.  But as series 14 of The Apprentice starts on Wednesday, Lord Sugar’s trusted aide thinks his no-nonsense pal’s talents are being under used.   Claude Littner is convinced the Government should tell Lord Sugar: “You’re hired” – to help with Brexit talks.  With the prospect of a no deal looking ever more likely, Claude, 69, said: “The fact people like Alan are not being used by this Government with Brexit is a real, real mistake. “There is a role for him and many other entrepreneurs who could at least advise on the best tactics, strategy, way of approaching [talks] – you wouldn’t want to miss out on that.” He argued that an entrepreneur with experience working in Europe could give a politician’s argument more weight.  But Claude does not think Lord Sugar will for not aim for high office, like his US counterpart and now President Donald Trump. “I don’t think he’s got that kind of ambition,” said Claude. Despite Lord Sugar’s many successes, his forays into social &shymedia, like those of Mr Trump, have not always worked out. Last month the peer was branded “sexist” after posting photo of a female shopkeeper showing ample cleavage. During the World Cup a tweet comparing the Senegal football team to people selling sunglasses on the beach sparked calls he be axed from the show. Claude said: “That was completely absurd. There’s nobody else who could do The Apprentice. He’s made the show his own, he’s fantastic – he is the show. Sometimes he does act inopportunely but that’s him. “I’ve been involved with Alan for a very long time. And where sometimes I would think being quiet is a better policy than actually speaking, Alan is one who says what he wants to say when he wants to say it. He’s not going to listen to what people say.  “That’s the nature of the man. He is direct – he’s got the strength of his convictions, and occasionally it doesn’t quite work out. “That doesn’t mean to say he’s not right, he just shouldn’t have expressed it that particular way at that particular time. Most of the time I think he’s spot on.” Lord Sugar, 71, will certainly not bite his tongue on The Apprentice as he reduces even the thickest-skinned hopeful to a quivering wreck in the boardroom. And they are unlikely to get sympathy from Claude or fellow aide Karren Brady. Stoney-faced Claude and his crushing analysis of the candidates can be as harsh as Lord Sugar’s verdicts. Claude said: “Normally the candidates are petried and don’t want to antagonise me – or anyone else – as that might have a detrimental effect on them.” But little can sway frosty Claude, even when the female candidates try flirting with him. He said: “The girls do all the time. I remember the interview with Katie Hopkins all those years ago, she was very flirty. It didn’t get her anywhere. If I was in their position I’d also try to be extra-friendly – why wouldn’t you? “I’m Jekyll and Hyde. I’m a good bloke but when it comes to business I’ve got a dferent persona. I’m stern. I never say hello, never give them eye contact.  “I’m rude – I ignore them completely and look at them with disdain, That way, nobody can say that I’ve got any favourites. “I’m not their nursemaid. I’m not going to say, ‘you poor thing, what a shame. Come on back in, I’ll help resolve the situation’. “I’m not the cause of their problem, they’re finding stress dficult – well, le is sometimes stressful, business is sometimes stressful and I’m not there to guide them through.” Sparks fly in the women’s team on Wednesday when the candidates travel to Malta. Claude said: “I could never understand why they are so antagonistic to each other. I think it’s a shame they react that way and can’t settle down earlier on and focus on the task – rather than on being catty to each other. “Maybe that’s human nature. They’re super excited, stressed, don’t know what’s expected from them or whether to put themselves forward. “Once the boys and girls are all mixed up they calm down. There’s a sort of mutual respect and understanding, whereas when it’s all girls or all guys they can’t help but get into conflict with each other.” Claude, who featured at the interviews stage of the show before replacing Nick Hewer as Lord Sugar’s aide in 2015, prefers The Apprentice to a former job as chief exec of Tottenham Hotspur.

title: brian reade never before serious
story: NewsopinionBrian Reade: Never before have serious events given us such belly laughsWhen Trump's UN speech was met with chortles, titters and giggles, we got the final confirmation that everything has gone seriously Pete TongShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBrian Reade23:51, 28 SEP 2018NewsopinionTrump is performing the rib-tickling, cringe-inducing stand-up set the world never asked for "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSomeone once said that laughter is the sun that drives winter from your face. If so, it might explain why we’ve still got the garden furniture out as we head into October. Not because of what’s in the sky but because it’s hard to recall a time when the so-called serious, grown-up events that are meant to shape the world have drawn so many belly laughs. Look at the entire United Nations General Assembly rolling around in stitches like Martian robots on the old Smash advert this week as the world’s most powerful man addressed them. When Donald Trump announced “my administration has accomplished more than almost any administration in the history of this country”, he was drowned out with guffaws. This has literally never happened in this very sombre organisation’s 73-year history. Was it his hair, the ease with which fiction leaves his puckered lips, or his rare show of modesty by using the word “almost”? Who knows.  But those delegates were smirking again when Trump accused the Chinese of interfering in US elections without mentioning the Russians, whose foreign minister stared at his phone, struggling to keep a straight face. Mind you, the rest of the world has been struggling to do the same ever since Vladimir Putin claimed the two hitmen he’d sent to Salisbury to take out Sergei Skripal were simply Songs of Praise fans who adored the cathedral so much they saved all their rubles to come over and gaze at its spire. Which was funny. But now it’s been revealed that one of those hitmen was an elite special forces colonel in Russian &shyintelligence who was awarded the country’s top military honour, it gets even funnier. How less elite can a special forces spook be than one who leaves his grinning mug plastered all over CCTV street cameras? I know, one who can’t bump off a pensioner whose greatest pleasure appears to be sitting in pubs and restaurants supping lager. Not that us Brits aren’t coming up with the laughs. UKIP MEP Lord Dartmouth has quit the party because it’s become too racist. Eh? That’s like quitting Mumsnet because all the women keep banging on about babies. Why else did he join?  Then, after Jeremy Corbyn’s &shyconference speech, there were the right-wing papers lampooning him in one breath as an eccentric Catweazle figure with loony policies, then in the next warning the Tories they need to take him seriously as a disillusioned Middle England could just buy them. Which brings us to Birmingham turning into Comedy Central next week when loose-dentured geriatrics spill their colostomy bags all over the Tory conference hall as their G-spots take direct hits from misty-eyed Brexiters fantasising about Victorian maids cycling through villages where everything, from the cricket flannels to the faces, are white. Remember last year when Theresa May’s cough-laden speech was so boring even the letters behind her dropped off?

title: baby given 1 chance survival
story: NewsBaby given 1% chance of survival after falling from third-floor window makes miracle full recoveryAnwar Nyanzi somehow began breathing unaided again and was standing up within weeks of the fallShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmy Sharpe23:03, 29 SEP 2018NewsAnwar Lule survived the plunge "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA baby who suffered dire injuries when he plunged 40ft from a window on to a pavement has made a full recovery. Anwar Nyanzi was 11 months old when he got on a chair while his aunt’s back was turned, hoisted himself on to a window ledge at the block of flats and fell out. With severe brain and spinal injuries, he had what was said to be a one per cent chance of survival. But he somehow began breathing unaided again and was standing up within weeks of the fall. His mum Hawa Rutansingwa said: “It was nothing short of a miracle. He pulled through despite having gone through the stuff of nightmares.”  She collapsed when she arrived at the scene of the accident and saw him. Hawa, 32, said: “His head was like a balloon. One of his eyes was almost popping out of his head... “But he proved himself a fighter.” Anwar fell from his aunt Fauzia’s third-floor flat in Croydon, South London, while Hawa was at work. Fauzia was sickened when she noticed Anwar had vanished and saw him motionless on the ground. She phoned 999 and called Hawa who rushed there too.  Over four days in intensive care at St George’s Hospital in Tooting, Anwar had brain surgery and treatment for broken ribs and arms. Hawa, who works in the healthcare sector, said: “I went with my brother and mother to kiss my son goodbye... It was horrible.” Anwar’s dad, who lives in Uganda, made arrangements to fly to Britain to say farewell too. Mum-of-three Hawa said the moment her lad astonished everyone by breathing for himself was “indescribable”.

story: NewsBritish MEAT set to rival European neighbours as first UK cured products hit supermarketsEXCLUSIVE: Back in 2010 there were just 10 British cured meat makers – but now there are more than 200, and Lidl are selling their waresShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNada Farhoud23:50, 29 SEP 2018NewsBritish charcuterie is about to hit the big time "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFirst we conquered Europe with our champion cheeses...then brilliant British bubbly beat French Champagne in blind testing. Now it’s the turn of our magnicent MEAT to give France’s charcuterie, Italy’s salami, Spain’s chorizo and Germany’s wurst a run for their money. British producers are creating mouth-watering cured meats developed through new techniques and fuelled by UK customers’ growing passion for top quality locally-sourced product. In 2010 there were just 10 British cured meat makers – eight years later that has risen dramatically to more than 200.  Now Lidl has become the first UK supermarket to stock an array of British-made charcuterie. The range – starting at &pound1.99 – includes Yorkshire chorizo, London fennel salami and Welsh sweet chorizo plus others sourced in Cornwall, Kent and Scotland. Makers include Black Hand Food in Hackney, east London and North Wall Charcuterie in Northumberland. And one UK company – Cannon &amp Cannon – has bagged a big six-figure deal to sell its meats with the German-owned supermarket giant.  Sean Cannon – who set up his business in London in 2011 – said: Artisan charcuterie is exploding. Britain is now producing distinctive, world-class products. We have the potential to make the best charcuterie in the world because we raise the best livestock.  “We are also not controlled by strict rules, such as those for Parma Ham, so we can be more adventurous with our creations. “Like many people, I thought you couldn’t make charcuterie in this country but the demand has just outstripped supply. “There are exceptional European hams that have taken 250 years to develop – there’s nothing else like them. “At the moment big Italian and French producers aren’t worried.

title: hero brit leaves life comfort
story: NewsDog-lover leaves behind le of comfort in UK to save neglected animals dumped in bins 1,600 miles awayLaura Myatt, 31, worked with horses in the English countryside before quitting her job to travel near to Transylvania with a mission to save innocent animalsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmy Sharpe18:31, 29 SEP 2018Updated00:00, 30 SEP 2018NewsMany of the dogs Laura rescues are in appalling health"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEach day dog lover Laura Myatt has the grim task of rling through a city’s bins, boxes and refuse bags looking for dumped puppies. Many of the abandoned pets are starving and abused, with gaping wounds or missing limbs. In winter they barely survive freezing temperatures, in summer they boil. And Laura, 31, faces a race against time to find and save the strays before the dog catchers who will put them down. She said: “I’ve seen so many horrendous things. If they were in Britain there would be outrage.” The charity worker in the Romanian city of Bacau, 1,600 miles from home and a “comfortable country lestyle” where she had a long-term partner.  In May 2016 Laura’s le changed when she started volunteering for Sadie’s Stray Dog Rescue, which has treated and &shyre-homed 700 pups to loving British families in the past four years. Laura said simply: “I saw things I couldn’t unsee.” Laura now lives in a “grotty” one-bed apartment in the city near Transylvania and works 15-hour days in a country where she does not speak the language. She split from her boyfriend before leaving the UK and quit an equestrian industry job. She said: “People probably think I’m mad but this is where my passion, future and calling is – we’re saving lives here. “Sadly, finding starving, stray dogs who are either barely surviving in freezing &shytemperatures or practically boiling alive in extreme heat is the norm. “Some are pets abandoned after &shybecoming too much work or money to take care of. Many have been abused, with gaping wounds or missing limbs. Some we find tied up or with limbs missing.” Each Romanian city has council-run shelters where government dog-catchers who patrol the streets take the strays.  But these are dubbed kill shelters by campaigners – as those which are unclaimed after 14 days are euthanised. Laura, from Lamport, Northants, said: “The conditions at public shelters are &shyappalling. We do all we can to avoid strays being sent there. “They are captured using poles. It’s inhumane and the animals scream in fear. Once they’re caught, most are slaughtered anyway to make room for the vast numbers of other strays that must come through the system. There’s very little real care there.” Sadie’s Stray Dog Rescue can cope with 250 pups and kittens and tries to take as many as they can. Laura has been exposed to hundreds of horric cases. She saw a female dog who had just one leg, the other three had been chopped off. Another caught in a wire snare trap had a huge wound around her middle, while a third had a leg hanging by a thread after being hit by a car. It was amputated and the dog made a full recovery. Laura said: “One called Nora we found with her nose nearly sliced off, but with some &shysurgery she made a full recovery and now has a wonderful home in the UK.”  But for some, such as a dog in the final stages of distemper, the rescuers are too late and the kindest action is to have the pooches put to sleep. Laura said: “What I used to think &shyimportant seems a million miles away.” She used to travel around Europe and America with her showjumping boyfriend and earned a steady wage renting out stables. She said: “I wasn’t born with a silver spoon in my mouth but I had a fortunate le in the UK. I used to have nice holidays, go to events, parties and balls, with a social le which meant an awful lot. “Now, my le is unglamorous but so much more rewarding. I am on call 24/7 for emergency pick-ups. “Each of our dogs requires feeding and cleaning, so I’ll get stuck in to that, and make sure worming and tick medications are up to date. “I’ll update weight and vaccination records for dogs that are due to travel and post pictures for our social media channels.” The pups she rescues are checked by vets, vaccinated and travel to the UK with proper paperwork as approved by Britain’s government standards.  The non-profit organisation, named after an adopted dog which was killed in Romania before she could leave for her new home, was founded in 2014 by Lesley Ford, from Banbury, Oxon. With over 9,000 Facebook followers, Sadie’s has 12 volunteers in the UK and four on the frontline in Romania. The country has 65,000 stray dogs in the capital Bucharest alone. We previously reported how almost 1,200 illegally smuggled puppies were seized at UK borders over the past two years. Many of this number – thought to be just the tip of the iceberg – came from Eastern Europe. She said: “It breaks my heart when criminals ship tiny puppies for quick cash. They undermine Romania’s legitimate re-homing operations and all the passion and hard work that goes into them.” Two months ago Bucharest authorities banned the sale of dog and cats at pet shops in a bid to boost adoptions from animal shelters like Sadie’s. In 2008 Romania outlawed abandoning, hurting and unnecessarily killing animals. But Laura said: “Unfortunately due to the sheer numbers of dogs, official bodies can often justy the decision to slaughter, while evidence of cruelty is just re here – so the laws don’t seem to count for much.”

title: madeleine mccanns dad gerry dreams
story: NewsMadeleine McCann's dad Gerry dreams about hugging his daughter again - and is convinced she's still aliveGerry broke down and sobbed as he relived his worst fears that Madeleine - who vanished 11 years ago in Portugal - had been "abused"Share&nbspByPatrick Hill21:46, 29 SEP 2018NewsMadeleine vanished in Portugal 11 years ago "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The father of missing Madeleine McCann wept as he insisted she is alive and told how he longs to hug her once again.  Gerry McCann spoke of his “painful” dreams about his daughter, who vanished in Portugal 11 years ago, just nine days short of her fourth birthday. Surgeon Gerry, 52, broke down and sobbed as he said he was “absolutely confident” she is alive – a view backed up by Scotland Yard’s plea for more funds to probe the mystery. He said: “It’s almost like an instinctive reaction... it’s just a feeling... but I do feel we will be reunited. “I just want to hug her and hold her and cry... a lot.”  Gerry also gave the most harrowing account yet of the pain he and we Kate, 52, have borne since Madeleine vanished from an Ocean Club apartment in Praia da Luz on May 3, 2007. He told of Kate’s screams at the discovery and how the couple were plagued by “the darkest thoughts” of their eldest daughter being “abused”. Gerry recalled the numbing moment that reality dawned that their girl was gone. He said: “I remember just being in the bedroom – the two of us just completely distraught. It was almost feral, the reaction and the pain, feeling helpless, alone. “I couldn’t get the darkest thoughts out of our minds that somebody had taken her and abused her.” A series of police probes have failed to shed any light on Madeleine’s whereabouts. But Gerry, from Rothley, Leics, said: “I thought about it a lot early on and what I was absolutely confident about is whatever had happened Madeleine was still alive and is still alive.  “There’s never a day goes by I don’t think about Madeleine and what might have happened. I have dreamt about her, including in the last few months, but it’s not frequent. “They’re painful when they happen.” Gerry revealed his agony during a BBC Radio 4 programme about the bond between fathers and daughters. It was broadcast as the Home Office last night considered whether to grant new funds to continue the &pound11.6million, seven-year British police investigation to find her. This week Scotland Yard formally applied to the Home Office for cash to extend Operation Grange for another six months and the move is expected to be rubber-stamped. Officers have investigated 60 people of interest and 560 lines of enquiry, but the last funding for the four-person Operation Grange team is due to run out today. The probe was launched in 2011 after the original Portuguese investigation was ruled “not fit for purpose”. Former Met Police counter-terorrism detective David Videcette backed new funding and said: “Good investigations take time.” Gerry spoke about how Madeleine’s siblings – Sean and Amelie, now 13 – helped him and Kate carry on.  He said: “The twins kept us going. Having two other children, trying to make sure they had enough love and attention that they deserved in their own right was incredibly important and thank God, I don’t know what it would have been like without them. “Thank God Sean and Amelie have had each other, but that they’ve missed out on having such a lovely big sister is very painful. Often my memories, happy memories, are of a girl who was almost four, but you look at Amelie and how she’s developed and you can’t help but think what would she look like. “Anniversaries are obviously really dficult and birthdays in particular, but also seeing Sean and Amelie going through all the stages I imagine Madeleine would.” Gerry choked back tears as he reminisced about cradling Madeleine in his arms, watching her go swimming and running around the garden before watching Dr Who. He went on: “The relationship I had with Madeleine was incredibly special. Between myself, Kate and Madeleine, it was like an equilateral triangle. “When Madeleine was very young she had really bad colic. She would get a lot of discomfort. I used to put her on my chest and rub her back and one of the things she used to do was pull the hairs on my chest really tightly. “It was quite painful and it seemed to ease her burden a little bit and I felt like I was taking some of it.  “I suppose all that contact time and skin-to-skin contact I did feel I had formed a really strong bond with her. “All parents think that their child is amazing and most children are, but some of the stuff I was able to do with Madeleine – the conversations she could have, her character, personality, it was really fantastic. “She really loved running around the garden and playing games and being chased and laughing. “And swimming, she loved swimming. You would take her to the leisure centre and she would just march out to her instructor with her cap on and goggles – smiling, no anxiety or fear. She was in there.” Gerry gave a gripping account of the moment he realised Madeleine vanished during their holiday in the Algarve. And he told of his immediate fear that she had been kidnapped by a paedophile. He said: “Kate came running back from the apartment screaming ‘Madeleine is missing, she’s gone’. I was like ‘She can’t be gone’. “I was looking in the bedroom, I was in cupboards, checking everywhere – even places where I knew she couldn’t be, under the kitchen sink.  “It was disbelief, shock, horror and then panic and terror. “I haven’t thought about those moments for a long time because, as you can imagine, it’s pretty painful. “I felt that every moment we couldn’t find her was worse and I remember being slumped on the floor and starting to call some of my family members and just saying ‘pray for her’ because I thought that was the only thing that might help at that point.” Gerry added: “There was an overwhelming feeling of helplessness that we couldn’t do anything and I think that experience we were feeling right at the centre of it was like a ripple or a tidal wave going out and crashing into all our family and friends as they found out what had happened. “That first night felt like it lasted forever. Obviously we didn’t sleep and went out again first thing as soon as it was light. Kate and I went out walking the streets of Praia da Luz shouting Madeleine’s name. I remember asking the police to get helicopters and heat seeking equipment and the thought somebody could be across the border into borderless Europe, driving her. Or Africa – the ports are a couple of hours away. I remember thinking ‘get the borders closed’. “It’s like the sickest you’ve ever been. It’s the worst of the adrenaline, fear, anxiety that manests itself in quite dramatic physical symptoms.”

story: NewsMars and Snickers bars announce MAJOR changes to their recipesHealthier ieties of chocolate bar will contain around 10g of protein and will be followed by low-calorie bars with less than 100 caloriesShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByStephen Hayward00:11, 30 SEP 2018NewsMars and Snickers are being given a healthy makeover "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMars and Snickers bars are to get a healthy makeover with big reductions in the amount of sugar they both contain, it has emerged. New versions of existing “more protein” ieties will be launched on the high street next January in a bid to tackle concerns about soaring obesity rates. Confectionery giant Mars Wrigley said the new Mars Protein will contain 17.5g of sugar, 40 per cent less than the current bars that help you “work, rest and play”. The Snickers Protein will contain 14.1g of sugar, which is 30 per cent less than the original. Each of the new kinds will also contain 10g of protein, around half that of both existing ones. Trade magazine The Grocer reported that the two new products will be followed later in 2019 by a new low-calorie range of “single-serve” bars.  These will contain less than 100kcal, around half of the original bars in some cases. The newly-merged firm said the range will include Mars, Snickers, Twix, Milky Way Crispy Rolls and Ripples. According to The Grocer these are the latest in a series of innovations since the appointment of Frenchman David Manzini as the firm’s new UK boss last year.

title: mum threes life saved after
story: NewsMum-of-three's le saved after routine Specsavers eye test reveals “ticking time bomb” brain tumourEXCLUSIVE: Simona Futter, 28, woke up on the morning of her daughter’s fth birthday to an excruciating headache, partial blindness and waves of intense nauseaShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLiz Dunphy17:12, 29 SEP 2018NewsSimona Futter, mum of three, was diagnosed with papilledema that causes pressure inside the skull following her eye examination "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum-of-three’s le was saved when a routine eye test at Specsavers revealed a “ticking time bomb” brain tumour. Simona Futter, 28, woke up on the morning of her daughter’s fth birthday to an excruciating headache, partial blindness and waves of intense nausea. Simona told Mirror: “I thought I had had a stroke in my sleep. Half my vision was gone, I couldn’t keep anything down, my headache was so, so bad and light was very annoying. “The doctor thought I had an inner ear infection, put me on antibiotics and sent me home. But the symptoms persisted. “One day I was driving home and suddenly felt so ill that I had to pull the top I was wearing out in front of me to throw up in it in the car. My clothes were wet through by the time I got home.  “I went for neurological tests at the hospital where they put me on a drip because I was so dehydrated from being ill, but they did not do a MRI and thought it was an inner ear infection there too. “The symptoms persisted for about four or five weeks so I thought I’d get my eyes tested.” In April 2016, Simona's eye test at Specsavers probably saved her le. Optometrist, Hardeep Bahra spotted swelling of the optic disc, a condition known as papilledema, when she looked at Simona’s eyes using a binocular microscope. Papilledema indicates raised pressure inside the skull, which could be caused by deadly conditions like a brain tumour or bleeding.  Simona, from Bracknell, was urgently referred to King Edwards Hospital in Windsor where a MRI scan confirmed papilledema. A second MRI detected a non-cancerous lump on her brain and a bleed during a follow-up consultation with her neurologist. Pressure on her brain was relieved with lumbar punctures but her tumour was not considered le-threatening so medics chose not to remove it. Simona said: “They found a lump in my head but it was so deep inside that operating on it could cause memory loss, or change my personality or affect my speech. So they decided not to operate. “But in December I woke up at about 2am feeling very unwell. I called mum and asked her to take the kids. “She came and called an ambulance which took me to Frimley Hospital where they said I had a brain bleed. “I was transferred to Charing Cross Hospital where I was for Christmas. Christmas was really sad in hospital. It was my first Christmas as a single mum and my kids were spending it with their dad.  “I didn’t even have time to buy them presents so my friend gave them presents for me. “I remember going to the bathroom and just crying it was so miserable. I had no glasses or contact lenses so I couldn’t see and I was sitting there blind and alone unable to see any other people in this enormous ward at Christmas. “We had to order our dinner from a menu but I couldn’t see so I ordered the wrong thing and didn’t even get potatoes.” Simona was discharged but in January 2018, she began to lose vision in her right eye prompting her to visit Specsavers again to see optometrist, Rina Binder. Rina diagnosed the  of papilledema and Simona was referred back to Charing Cross Hospital. “It was just after the New Year so the hospital was really busy and I was waiting for nine hours. “When they saw me they said my vascular tumour kept bleeding so they decided to operate because the risk of having a stroke and the damage that could cause outweighed the risks of surgery. “The tumour was 4.5cm but they had to wait and monitor me in hospital until the swelling in my head went down enough so they could operate. “It was like a ticking time bomb in my head. I never knew when it was going to bleed again and I just wanted it out. “Eight days later they operated. 15 doctors were there, Charring Cross is a training hospital too so some surgeons watched the operation to learn.

title: radio dj prominent lgbt activist
story: NewsRadio DJ and prominent LGBT activist used Grindr app to 'meet boy, 15, in Tesco for cuddle and a peck'Radio DJ Christopher Oatway, 26, from Stockport, used dating app Grindr to arrange a meeting with 'a 15-year-old boy' at a supermarket in Chorlton, ManchesterShare&nbspByAndrew Bardsley17:35, 29 SEP 2018NewsThe prominent LGBT activist used Grindr to speak to young boys "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA prominent LGBT activist used Grindr to arrange to 'meet a 15-year-old boy for a cuddle and peck' in a Tesco store. Community radio station radio DJ Christopher Oatway, 26, used the dating app to speak to someone who he believed was a teenage boy.  But when he arrived at Tesco in Chorlton, Manchester, in July last year, he realised the child was in fact an adult.  They demanded Oatway hand over cash, threatening to report him to the police  he didn't cough up.  He handed over &pound50, reports the Manchester Evening News.  Oatway's crime was exposed a year later when he arranged to meet another '15-year-old boy', who turned out to be a member of a 'paedophile hunter' group.  Manchester Crown Court heard Oatway - who was involved in organising LGBT pride events in Stockport, Trafford and Rochdale - had been talking to someone purporting to be called 'Cody' on Grindr. They later agreed to meet in Manchester city centre. There Oatway, from Stockport, was met by a man. Police seized items from his home, including a mobile phone. Analysis revealed the Grindr conversations a year earlier and details of the meet-up at Tesco.  Oatway, who has no previous convictions, appeared at court relating to the earlier incident in Chorlton. The Crown Prosecution Service offered no evidence relating to the incident in Manchester city centre. He was sentenced to a two-year community order, including a sex offender treatment program, after admitting attempting to engage in sexual communication with a child. Oatway must also sign the sex offender's register for five years.  Defending, Brendan O'Leary said that Oatway was 'genuinely remorseful' and 'accepts what he did was wrong'. He said the messages exchanged on Grindr showed that Oatway did not seek to engage in sexual activity with a child. When that was said it was genuine, it wasn't a ruse to trick the person into meeting him, Mr O'Leary said. References submitted to the court spoke highly of Oatway, his barrister said, referencing his charity work, fundraising and how he is active in the LGBT community.

title: christine blasey ford should saluted
story: NewsopinionChristine Blasey Ford should be saluted for her 'courage' over Brett Kavanaugh sex claimsThe crimes of our youth should not be cut very much slack  they are alleged sexual assaultsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySaira Khan20:33, 29 SEP 2018NewsopinionChristine Blasey Ford "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe all make stupid &shymistakes when we’re young. Getting it wrong is how we grow up and learn to get it right. So when looking back at youthful misdeeds and misdemeanours it’s only fair to cut people a little slack. But when those mistakes are sex crimes, then the amount of slack that’s cut should be very, very small indeed. Dame Judi Dench touched on the issue this week when she was asked about her friend Kevin Spacey being replaced in films and TV shows in the wake of sex assault allegations. Spacey apologised for past behaviour but denied alleged assaults, some of which police are investigating.  Dame Judi said: “He is and was a most wonderful actor,” then asked  we would now “go back through history” to remove “anyone who has misbehaved in any way”. She has a point. We cannot just wipe all of Spacey’s work from the archive and pretend he never existed. But sexual assault is not just “misbehaving”, is it? It’s an offence, it’s a violation. It can damage a person’s mental health in a way that effectively destroys their le. Take TV legend Bill Cosby’s accusers. Only one of them, Andrea Constand, has seen justice. As the 81-year-old actor – described by the judge as a sexually violent predator – was carted off in handcuffs this week to begin a jail sentence of three to 10 years for assaulting her, I thought of the dozens of other women who bravely came forward to accuse him. Decades later they are still struggling to come to terms with being drugged and molested by a man we thought of as America’s dad, but who was actually the devil in disguise.  Because the time window for prosecuting him had passed, he never had to answer to any of them. Meanwhile, in any country you look at, only a small percentage of sex assaults ever get reported, a smaller percentage go to court and a tiny number result in convictions. To stand up in public and expose yourself to the hatred of someone who has already abused you, and the scorn of those who decided you were lying before you even opened your mouth, is a level of hell most of us will thankfully never know. So I salute the courage of psychology professor Dr Christine Blasey Ford who – despite admitting to being terried – told a US Senate hearing this week she believed Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh was going to rape her at a teenage house party in the 1980s. She claims the judge, Donald Trump’s conservative pick for the top US court, forced her on to a bed, tried to strip her, and covered her mouth to stop her screaming, leading her to fear suffocation. She was 15 at the time, he was 17. He says it never happened. Dr Ford earlier took a lie detector test, and passed. He has not taken one. Two other women have come forward to accuse Kavanaugh – one says he exposed his penis and shoved it in her face at a party. Another says he was present when she was gang raped at a party in the 1980s. He denies both offences.

title: great pumpkin asteroid shaped like
story: News'Great Pumpkin' asteroid shaped like SKULL set to fly past Earth just after HalloweenThe creepy comet, which was given its vegetable nickname by experts at NASA, is heading this way again after last visiting in 2015Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByPippa Allen-Kinross22:46, 29 SEP 2018NewsThe comet looks eerily like a skull "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A skull-shaped asteroid which has earned the nickname of 'Great Pumpkin' is set to fly past Earth just after Halloween .   The comet was first named after the spooky vegetable by scientists at NASA , after it flew past Earth on October 31, 2015.  Officially called the TB1456 asteroid, it came as close as 300,000 miles away from the planet back in 2015 - or 1.3 times the distance of the moon from Earth. It will be heading back this way on November 11, but is expected to be even further away and pass by at around 24 million miles away. This is about a quarter of the distance between the Earth and sun.  The asteroid has been described as a death comet, because it's believed to be a dead comet but also because of its unusual skull-like shape. First spotted by NASA's Infrared Telescope Facility  in Manua Kea, Hawaii, it's unnerving features were revealed on detailed radar images taken by the Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico. In 2015, NASA said the comet was approximately 200ft  in diameter. At the time, Kelly Fast, IRTF program scientist at NASA, said: The IRTF data may indicate that the object might be a dead comet, but in the Arecibo images it appears to have donned a skull costume for its Halloween flyby.

title: as it happens dundee united v ross county
story: Cries of &#8216Csaba out&#8217 rang around Tannadice as United slumped to an embarrassing defeatShambolic, abject, and abysmal are all words that can be used to describe Dundee United&#8217s performance as they were humiliated on their own patch by Ross County.The Terrors were hopeless at the back and pretty blunt going forward as the Staggies romped to all three points. It is hard to defend United manager Csaba Laszlo now and it would be no surprise  he is given his jotters after this most horric of days.It started when eventual hat-trick hero and former Tangerine Billy Mckay opened the scoring from close range on 11 minutes, knocking in a Josh Mullin cross.The only chink of light in the game came six minutes later as Pavol Safranko got on the end of Fraser Aird&#8217s delivery to guide the ball past Scott Fox in the away net.From there United laboured and County took advantage. Scoring the most simple and avoidable goals &#8211 often carbon copies of each other.The second came on 29 minutes after a Jamie Robson mistake played in Mullin to square for Mckay to knock in.On 41 minutes the same problems United had faced all game down their left-hand side were there for all to see as Sean Kelly inswinging free-kick went all the way through past Matej Rakovan in the home net. A horrible goal to concede with no communication evident and the defence at sixes and sevens.Soon after the restart the Staggies put the game to bed when Mullin and Mckay linked up again with the former this time tapping in from a yard out on 50 minutes.Mullin turned provider, once more, two minutes later laying Mckay&#8217s hat-trick on a plate for him and the Northern Irishman gobbled it up from a matter of inches out.Csaba tried to change things for the Tangerines, but by this point the punters had seen enough and were leaving in their droves and calling for his head in the process, as he brought on Stewart Murdoch and Fraser Fyvie to try to change things on 56 minutes.And three minutes later Murdoch summed up the Terrors afternoon as he was shown a straight red for a stamp on Jamie Lindsay.It capped what was United&#8217s worst performance in years as County saw out the rest of the game with little problem. Is it time up for Csaba?Full details in live blog.&nbsp

title: cammy kerr calls on dundee to show dee fiant spirit
story: Cammy Kerr has called on everyone at Dundee to revive the Dee-fiant spirit to get out of the trouble they find themselves in at the bottom of the Premiership table.The 3-0 home defeat to Hibs last weekend leaves the Dark Blues still stuck on zero points after six league fixtures.A lelong fan of the club, Kerr, however, knows Dundee have got through tougher situations than this in their history.Though he admits they’ll need exactly the same “character” as the club showed to overcome a 25-point deduction in 2010  they are to get off the foot of the ision.He said: “As you see the games going and the points staying the same, it is dficult but that’s why you are a football player and have got to this stage and you need to deal with ups and downs and struggles along the way.“This club has had plenty of struggles in its time, it’s had points deductions and all sorts of things – it’s now about showing that character within the club that I believe no other club has.“We just have to find that within ourselves and push it on and make sure nothing stops us in this search for a victory.“We had a poor start a couple of years ago but we turned things around and that’s what I’m trying to get at.“It’s so dficult but being a Dundee fan and seeing things the way I have over the years, I know there is nothing that should allow this club to say no.“Everyone pulling together, the office staff, kitchen staff, the youth boys, everyone, just keep smiling, keep plugging away and it’s going to turn, I’m positive of that.”Honest as ever, Kerr admits this season just plainly hasn’t been good enough from Dundee.“If you let things get out of hand it’s like a disease that spreads,” he added.“It’s all confidence-related and, as the manager spoke about before, we just need a goal to get us in front.“However, at the same time,  we are going behind in games, we can show resilience that we don’t lie down but fight for every ball, every tackle, everything we have in us, we keep fighting to the end. We just seem to be falling short just now and it’s not good enough.“There’s nothing else for it, it’s the same old cliched stuff – you’ve just go to keep fighting away.“You need to be ready to go on the training field, pushing yourself to the max every day.“We have to put in the hard yards and that’s the only way it will turn.“I know the fans and everyone at the club is frustrated, they’re obviously used to seeing better times than this, but there is still time to get our season going.“That’s the only positive – there’s another game in a few days’ time, a massive game against Hamilton and we’ve got to go and make sure we get a victory.“I know, it’s easy saying that and the punters will be sick to the back teeth of people saying ‘next week, next week’ but it’s the only thing for it.”Hamilton against Dundee has been a grudge match over the past few years and last season at New Douglas Park was one of the stand-out moments for the Dark Blues as they came from behind to win the game in the 97th-minute through A-Jay Leitch-Smith.Kerr added: “Last season at Hamilton was amazing, an incredible finish to the game and that again was a resilient performance full of character within the group.“It’s dficult being positive after Saturday’s defeat and having no points from the first six games but we have to go there, knowing how hard it is down there, it’s an absolute dogfight.“They got a great result last week but it’s a game of football, 90 minutes, and  we get ourselves on top we can win the game on Saturday.”

title: coffee giant starbucks plans to open second drive thru in dundee
story: Coffee giant Starbucks could open a second drive-thru branch on Dundee’s ring road in the near future.The chain opened its first drive-thru at Wester Gourdie Industrial Estate earlier this year, and has now submitted a proposal for another.If approved, the branch would occupy land on Afton Way, close to the city’s Morrisons store.Representatives for Morrisons, which owns the entire site at Afton Way, say the planned shop would match the “signicant” growth of drive-thru coffee shops across the country.It would also serve a iety of people from passing motorists on the A90 through to nearby residents.The new proposal,  approved by Dundee city planners, would also create new jobs, and contribute to ongoing regeneration efforts in the North East.In a statement, representatives for Morrisons said: “The proposed small-scale drive- thru unit will form a complementary addition to the existing Morrisons store.“It will also generate a number of job opportunities for local people.”The application also hints at further development to come at Afton Way.Initial talk of an expansion on the site began as early as January 2013 – with other potential developments in future including a pub.Diagrams included with the Starbucks proposals detail a new, more convenient entrance to the site from the southbound A90 Forfar Road.However, this is likely to form part of a separate planning application in due course.And Morrisons also had a plan to mody and expand its petrol station approved in October last year.Starbucks’ latest move to build on Dundee’s ring road comes at a time of intense interest from developers on the Kingsway.Alongside the now-opened Starbucks drive-thru at Myrekirk, plans have also been approved for a retail complex on Kingsway East at Craigie.That development will boast a Lidl, a car dealership and a Costa Coffee drive-thru.Starbucks also has a sit-in coffee shop at the Overgate Centre.

title: csaba happy to be able to call on quality as dundee united prepare for ross county
story: Boss Csaba Laszlo will be pleased to be able to turn to his bench for support as his Dundee United side host Ross County at Tannadice.Csaba will welcome club captain Fraser Fyvie back to the fold after he missed last Saturday’s 2-0 win over Falkirk due to him not being risked on the articial surface so soon after recovering from a knee injury.He will be joined in the matchday party by winger Billy King as a few other absentees fight back to contention.“With these players coming back it will create more competition and up the quality in training,” Csaba said.“Sam Stanton and Stewart Murdoch are back in training with the team, while Nicky Clark will need another week.“It is important to get these players back to speed.”On Fyvie, Csaba added: “It was a frustration to have a player that can’t play.“We also have to accept that he is a player who has been injured long-term.“It has not just been an easy injury that takes a little time to recover from.“Psychologically, you must also be ready for this kind of match.“As a manager, you have to accept it when a player says ‘This isn’t the best game for me, on the articial pitch’.“For that reason he didn’t play but he will be OK for the Ross County match.”One player Csaba has, sadly, ruled out for the forseeable future is Lewis Toshney.“He has been out for a year so it is not easy for him.“He is fighting to come back.“I am happy that he can train but I don’t think we can talk just now about the first team.”

title: designer says maggies penguin parade in dundee can inspire future artists
story: The success of charity art trails highlights the positive effect sculpture can play in bolstering civic pride, a University of Dundee academic has said.Janice Aitken, associate dean for public and community engagement at Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art and Design, said that the success of campaigns like the city’s Maggie’s Penguin Parade would also help to inspire future generations of artists.Janice, who created the original design used for the cancer charity’s summer fundraiser, made the comments ahead of speaking at Dundee Arts Cafe this coming Tuesday.“It’s very important to celebrate a rich culture and heritage in any community,” she said.“Having a sense of fun and civic pride makes any city a more positive place to live.”Janice will speak about the benefits of public art and her association with the Penguin Parade, which saw 80 dferent sculptures put in place throughout Dundee over the summer.

title: dundee are currently the worst football team in the world

title: dundee gaffer neil mccann hoping lengthy injury list eases for crunch hamilton clash
story: Dundee boss Neil McCann is hoping his walking wounded recover in time for today’s vital Premiership game against Hamilton kicks off.The Dens gaffer is under pressure to arrest his side’s run of straight defeats – six in the league, seven in all competitions – as the Dark Blues head to Lanarkshire to take on Accies.Martin Canning’s men sit on six points and can move nine clear of their relegation rivals with a second win in two, after a 3-0 thumping of St Mirren last week.Neil will have at least one addition to his options after winger Roarie Deacon declared himself available for action.After a y period out, caused by an injury to his ankle picked up in the last game of last season against Partick which required surgery, it’s likely the former Arsenal man will have to settle for a place on the bench.Last week’s 3-0 defeat to Hibs saw Kharl Madianga, Calvin Miller and Benjamin Kallman all limp off.Finnish striker Kallman’s problem was cramp and won’t keep him out today while Madianga and Miller’s injuries were muscle based and it remains to be seen how long they may be out for.The club are hopeful Josh Meekings will be back fit after a thigh injury picked up against Motherwell four weeks ago.He missed the defeat to Hibs, though, Neil may be tempted to stick with his two loan signings Andy Boyle and Ryan Inniss in any case.At the top end of the field, the Dens boss will be hoping targetman Sofien Moussa has recovered from his knock picked up before the loss to Hibs to give him another option in attack.Meanwhile, Kenny Miller will serve the final game of his two-match suspension today.

title: dundee music star be charlotte stars in african festival this weekend
story: Dundee pop star Be Charlotte is performing at Lake of Stars Malawi Arts Festival in Africa this weekend.Lake of Stars is one of the country’s most respected arts festivals, attracting performers and visitors from across the globe.Charlotte Brimner, also known as Be Charlotte, recently signed a major deal with Columbia/ Sony music and also performed at the 3D Festival in celebration of the opening of V&ampA Dundee.She is widely regarded as one of the most exciting prospects in Scottish contemporary music.Charlotte will share the stage with some of Scotland’s finest musicians and poets, including Michael Pedersen of Neu! Reekie! and Scottish Album of the Year Award nominee Kobi Onyame.Supported by Creative Scotland, the festival is celebrating its 15th anniversary by connecting artists from the Scottish music and poetry scenes with artists from Malawi.It runs until Sunday.&nbsp

title: dundees bid for big oil projects rejected because port is too shallow
story: Dundee’s bid to become a centre for large-scale oil and gas decommissioning projects was rejected because the approach to the port is “too shallow”.Despite owner Forth Ports investing £10 million to ensure the port was capable of handling large-scale projects,  Shetland was chosen this month as the best site to carry out large-scale oil and gas decommissioning.Consultants Ernst and Young decided Dundee was unsuitable after just the first of its three testing stages.Its full report is still to be published but energy minister Paul Wheelhouse revealed the reason for Dundee’s rejection in a response to a written parliamentary question by Conservative MSP Bill Bowman.He said the approach to the docks only has a depth of six metres, not the nine required, and with dredging work, the approach to Dales Voe in Shetland will be 24 metres deep.He said: “Although Dundee is suitable for a range of decommissioning works, because the approach depth was insufficient for those projects requiring a deep water port, it was therefore not assessed further than Stage one.”Stuart Wallace, chief operating officer of Forth Ports, which owns the Port of Dundee, hit back, saying the dock was easily capable of handling large-scale decommissioning work.He said: “The Port of Dundee has the largest permanent quayside crane, strongest quayside and biggest indoor decommissioning facility in Scotland.“Dundee regularly welcomes large jack-up rigs into the Tay and can handle all vessels any other east of Scotland port can accept.“There are only three vessels operating in the market that require 30m+ water depth, however this is a very small part of the market.“With additional investment, the approach channel to the port could be enhanced.”Mr Bowman said: “It is disappointing to be told Dundee did not pass the first test, although the SNP has still yet to publish the details.”

title: exclusive argentina legend claudio caniggia to return to dundee
story: Dundee fans haven’t had much to cheer recently but they will be given a lt with news Claudio Caniggia is set to make a  to the city.The 50-times capped Argentine international – and former strike-partner of Diego Maradona – will be back in Dundee at the Whitehall Theatre on Thursday November 29.Caniggia will be joined on stage by renowned Dundee-supporting journalists Patrick Barclay and Alan Patullo, to discuss his World Cup heroics, that goal against Brazil, his time in Italian football, being offered the chance to  to the national team at 43 years of age, and, of course, his time with the Dark Blues.His arrival at Dens Park 18 years ago, stunned Scottish football and attracted international media attention.Although 33-years-old when he signed for Ivano Bonetti’s Dundee in September 2000, a debut goal at Pittodrie proved there was no doubt that he would still be a star in the Scottish game.Despite being at Dens for less than a season, Caniggia remains idolised by the Dundee supporters and was inducted in to the Club’s Hall of Fame in 2009.The evening will be hosted by broadcaster David Tanner.During his time at Dens, Caniggia wore the No 33 shirt each time he played. Accordingly, tickets for the event are priced at £33.Tickets – including a limited number of VIP Meet &amp Greet briefs – are on sale from 9am tomorrow morning by logging on to thelongestforty.&nbspHelp For Kids are the event charity partner, with a donation being made to the charity for the benefit of local children, and tickets being made available for families who might not have otherwise been able to attend.

title: hamilton boss martin canning wont be shed a tear for under pressure dundee counterpart neil mccann
story: Hamilton boss Martin Canning insists he cannot afford to take any notice of Neil McCann’s plight ahead of Saturday’s clash with bottom side Dundee.Pressure is piling on the Dens Park manager after six straight Ladbrokes Premiership defeats and a Betfred Cup exit to Ayr United.However, Canning noted his side beat St Mirren 3-0 at home on Saturday for their first win in four matches, to give Accies some respite of their own.He said: “You’ve got to go and do your own job and my job on Saturday is to try to get Hamilton Accies three points and  we can do that we’ll be delighted.“That’s just football. We know Dundee will be desperate for the points.“We’ve got to make sure we match that and that gives us the best opportunity.“We’re all going to have spells when things don’t go our way.“I’m pretty sure, same as I do, he’ll believe in his players that they can go and win games and he’ll work hard to try to make that happen.“One result can make you feel a lot better.“I think at times last season, half-a-dozen clubs went through runs of losing four, five, six games and it can happen in this league quite easily.“I thought Dundee were good against St Mirren – very good.“The goalkeeper makes a mistake and they lose the game and from there it snowballs into a poor run of results, so it can happen so easily.“The flip side of it is, you go and win two or three games in a row and it’s a completely dferent complexion.”

title: neil mccann urges his dundee players to give themselves an easier ride
story: Neil McCann has urged his players to “give themselves an easier ride” at Hamilton on Saturday as they search for a first result of the campaign.The Dark Blues have endured a woeful start to the Premiership season, losing their opening six fixtures and scoring just twice.At the start of that run was also a 3-0 home defeat in the Betfred Cup to Ayr United, making it seven defeats on the trot.In none of those matches have Dundee managed to put themselves in front and their gaffer is desperate for the players to at least give themselves a chance of picking up a result.In order to do that, they’ll have to get the better of an Accies side high on confidence after a 3-0 thumping of St Mirren in match that has had a bit of extra spice over the past few years.And despite extra pressure on him to get the result, Neil still has faith in his side.He said: “It’s a huge game, they always have been against Hamilton.“The games against Livingston, Hamilton, Kilmarnock are going to be so important and then Hibs and Hearts.“We are still striving for that first win and we’ll keep trying to give everything to get ourselves that first goal that can at least put ourselves in a position to go and get that first win.“I still think that you could see in the first 45 minutes last Saturday, there is a team there.“I would just love to see them give themselves an easier ride by putting themselves in front.”The Dens gaffer is also hopeful of having some extra bodies back fit after a punishing injury-hit spell.Josh Meekings, Genseric Kusunga, Nathan Ralph and Sofien Moussa all missed the defeat to Hibs with injury while Kenny Miller was suspended.He’ll also miss Saturday’s trip to Hamilton while Kharl Madianga, Calvin Miller and Benjamin Kallman all added to the injury worries last weekend.The good news is winger Roarie Deacon is nearing a  after getting 45 minutes under his belt in a bounce game this week.Neil added: “We’ve not had an easy run of it and it’s been tough to get a settled side out.“We had Glen Kamara and Ryan Inniss back from injury lay-offs on Saturday but it’s been problematic in terms of that.“I have been happy with the squad,  I can get them all fit it would be welcome but we’ve not been able to get that.”

title: taysiders getting happier while fife folk becoming more anxious report
story: People living across Tayside are getting happier while those in Fe have experienced a signicant rise in anxiety, according to a report by the Office for National Statistics.Angus has seen the biggest jump in happiness anywhere in the region with a 2.7% increase on the previous year.During the same period, Dundee saw a rise of 0.9%, while Perth and Kinross experienced a dip of 1%.Fe also suffered a decrease in happiness, dropping 0.9% following a sharp rise the year before, but charted a further decline across the three other wellbeing factors covered in the report.The report notes key influences that determine overall happiness, including local factors such as crime, community cohesion, employment and education.People living in the Western Isles were found to be the happiest anywhere in the country, while those in the Highlands were the happiest on the mainland.Scotland remains the second happiest nation in the UK overall, second only to Northern Ireland, with England taking up last place.Scots are 0.7% happier than they were in 2016-17 but the data shows a decrease in the longer term, with a 2.6% fall since the earliest records in 2011-12.Dundee saw a 3.2% rise in le satisfaction and a 3.4% increase in terms of how worthwhile people think their actions are, but also experienced a sharp rise in anxiety levels.Locals in Dundee experienced an 8.9% increase from the previous year, with only Fe reporting a bigger jump across the area at 11.1%.Toni Giugliano, policy manager at the Mental Health Foundation Scotland, warned that there is a “very clear link” between areas with high levels of social deprivation and mental ill-health.

title: we are not manchester city csaba explains why he feels being dundee united boss is the hardest job in scottish football
story: There were some cursory glances around the Press room at the Falkirk Stadium after Dundee United’s 2-0 win on Saturday when boss Csaba Laszlo, almost out of nowhere, asserted the following.“The most dficult job in the Scottish Championship, or Scottish football at the moment, is to be the manager of Dundee United.”He qualied that statement by adding that it is also dficult for his players to pull on the black and tangerine but his remarks did pique the interests of those gathered.It wasn’t so much disagreement or astonishment that filled the room but more a sense of being taken aback by the brutal honesty of a man who has been under such pressure of late.He eased some of the weight on his shoulders with the result at Falkirk under what were strange circumstances – namely going up against predecessor Ray McKinnon in the opposite dugout for a side sitting bottom and pointless.And it was clear that, despite assertions by some that Csaba is daft or clueless, he was very aware of the ramications had he not got the right result.“We showed good team spirit under pressure, they handled it positively,” Csaba commented as he laid out his case to the gathered press.“Now we can close this chapter and look ahead to the next game which will be very dficult.“This is the third season where the fans have been disappointed to be in the second tier and we are talking about a very massive, strong and passionate club that wants to be in Premiership.“If something doesn’t go right immediately you have noise which is OK but we don’t want to hide behind anything.“We have this pressure and we have to accept.“We don’t want to spend one more year in the Championship – it’s not good.“The Dundee United fans don’t want to hear that from the board, the manager or anybody. They want to have the target of promotion and winning the league.“This is pressure, this is normal but you have to understand we have a budget that isn’t any higher than other teams in the main.“You have to bring a team together. We had 19 players leave and 16 players come in for the new season.“We can’t click our fingers and have the team work fantastically.“There are rules at the club about how many or which kind of players we can bring in within our budget.“It is not easy, we are not Manchester City with an owner behind you who can give you £20 million to go and spend.“We have to work with the budget we have to get the best for the club.“The Dundee United board have done a fantastic job. It is not easy to convince players from abroad to come to the Scottish Championship with everything else around.”It was quite a defence – but probably one that was coming after weeks of trying to keep a lid on it following poor results against Alloa and Morton.Yes, he has not had his troubles to seek with injury and scrutiny from all angles but it seems to be just the beginning for Csaba in his most tough of jobs.In the next four weeks they take on title rivals Ross County, Ayr United, Partick Thistle and Inverness. They kick off that run at home to County on Saturday.“I don’t just look at one game being more important than the other because you can’t afford to take any game lightly,” Csaba added. “You have to take every opponent seriously, whether they be at the top, middle or bottom of the league.”

title: xplore bosses apologise for disruption to dundee buses due to driver shortage
story: BUS bosses have apologised following claims dozens of services have been cancelled in the last few weeks.Xplore Dundee says a shortage of drivers is causing serious disruption to routes throughout the city.One passenger claims he spent almost an hour waiting for a service as a result.The Tele understands dozens of cancellations have occurred, with many being announced on electronic boards at bus stops.Normal service is still to resume, but a spokeswoman for Xplore Dundee said they are “seeing improvements”.She said: “We’re sorry for the disruption currently affecting some of the services in our network and for any inconvenience caused to customers. We’re currently experiencing operational dficulties due to a temporary driver shortage. This issue is being actively worked on and we are already seeing improvements.“To keep passengers up to date, the real time information boards within shelters are programmed to show any change to services. All the relevant authorities have been informed of this situation and are being updated regularly on our progress.“Once again, we apologise for this short-term reduction in service and want to reassure customers we’re working very hard to resolve this as quickly as we can to resume normal operations.”A spokesman for the Traffic Commissioner’s office, which deals with complaints relating to bus operators, said they were aware of the current issues in relation to the punctuality of Xplore Dundee services but could not comment on a pending case.Back in June, the Traffic Commissioner fined Xplore Dundee £8,700 after repeated complaints about late and early-running services throughout the city.A report was submitted by Bus Users Scotland about punctuality failings and the services cited included the 9, 10, 15, 17 and 23 buses.The financial penalty was imposed after the Traffic Commissioner opted not to pursue a further investigation into the issues.One bus user, who wished to remain anonymous, said he found himself waiting almost an hour for a bus to Charleston last week. He said: “Journeys are basically going missing as far as I can see.“I have a family member who works for Xplore and it seems drivers are going off sick and they can’t replace them.“Myself and other people have been waiting up to an hour for buses – it’s shocking.“It was only the other week that I was waiting on a bus to go to Charleston and all I was seeing on the electronic board was that it had been cancelled.“The company weren’t able to send another one on and I was having to wait, that really shouldn’t be happening.“As far as I am aware this has been going on for quite a few weeks now. There’s no signs of it getting any better but something needs to be done about it.“I was informed that the Traffic Commissioner was aware of it so hopefully they will take it seriously.”
